hgabor
2016-09-06 07:32
what do we want to do with these kind of errors: https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/job/fabric-verify-x86_64/914/console those test resources seem to be problematic as they are used by multiple branches and pending Gerrit changesets that need different settings

simon
2016-09-06 08:27
what do you mean by settings?

hgabor
2016-09-06 08:33
I mean that main and feature/convergence need different chaincode interfaces to be implemented in the test code so only one of them will work. on the other side, if you upload a new gerrit changeset, and change something related to that test you will have to create a PR to the Github of fabric-resources and 1) if that is merged your changeset will pass the tests but master and feature will most probably fail 2) your changeset will fail the tests

simon
2016-09-06 08:39
oh

hgabor
2016-09-06 08:40
people usually work this around by having forks of fabric resources but that leads to source pointing to non-official repos

simon
2016-09-06 08:46
yea that test isn't good

hgabor
2016-09-06 08:47
we should somehow find ways to permanently fix that

hgabor
2016-09-06 09:05
any ideas?

simon
2016-09-06 09:28
not fetch from http?

garisingh
2016-09-06 09:34
@simon - the test that fails is actually the one which tests the ability to deploy chaincode from a remote repository so unfortunately not fetching from http is not an option for this particular test. (BTW - https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/901/ puts in a temporary fix for this on the master branch - basically points master at a different remote repo for the chaincode) The fact that these tests are failing is actually good IMHO because (and I know I sound like a broken record) we have got to find a way to version packages / interfaces for different releases of the fabric.

simon
2016-09-06 09:34
well, fetch from a locally created http server

garisingh
2016-09-06 09:35
if you take a look at the "fix" I attempted, the idea was that we could use something like http://gopkg.in in conjunction with branching / tagging

garisingh
2016-09-06 09:35
@simon - possible but that server would need to implement the github metadata

simon
2016-09-06 09:35
i never found that interface useful tho

simon
2016-09-06 09:35
you should ship your own code

simon
2016-09-06 09:35
not have the server fetch it from somewhere

garisingh
2016-09-06 09:36
"go get" only supports specific remote locations and they are all source code control systems - so a straight http download does not work

simon
2016-09-06 09:36
you're not guaranteed that the server will actually produce the same files

simon
2016-09-06 09:36
why do we need to test whether go get can fetch from http?

garisingh
2016-09-06 09:36
the other option for chaincode specifically is that we move to a model where you always vendor the dependencies

simon
2016-09-06 09:36
or from git

simon
2016-09-06 09:36
we know that it can

garisingh
2016-09-06 09:38
We are testing the end to end deployment of chaincode from a remote repository - I think the test is valid if we are going to support the functionality. Personally, I think we can (and should) remove deployment of chaincode from remote repositories in v1 since we now have the SDK which can deploy chaincode from your local system

simon
2016-09-06 09:38
yes, i agree

garisingh
2016-09-06 09:39
BUT - it still does not solve the problem of breaking interfaces across releases. We need a strategy for properly packaging and versioning the chaincode package

garisingh
2016-09-06 09:41
Go 1.7 offers the ability (its experimental) to actually ship packages as binaries - that might be interesting to look at as well when it comes to creating a proper SDK/package for developing chaincode

simon
2016-09-06 09:42
i think the shim needs to be broken out and versioned

hgabor
2016-09-06 09:46
@garisingh where is your fix attempt?

hgabor
2016-09-06 09:53
I like the idea of this versioning

garisingh
2016-09-06 09:54
it has been merged already on master -- https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/901/

hgabor
2016-09-06 09:55
oh so I gave +2 because I also liked it when I reviewed it :smile:

jchenibm
2016-09-06 09:59
has joined #fabric-maintainers

hgabor
2016-09-06 10:40
how exactly will we use this? when should one increase the version number?

garisingh
2016-09-06 10:53
@hgabor - in many ways that is the question of the hour. Here's my take / proposal: 1) We actually need to start cutting releases - I propose we have release branches (perhaps we can also use tags as well) 2) Each time we cut a release branch we increment the version of the master branch 3) Currently it looks like "version" is set via an environment variable in the Makefile (which will work) but perhaps if we have a coordinated version strategy we can actually at least put the major version in the metadata package

garisingh
2016-09-06 10:53
BUT - we have an issue with the convergence branch right now - what version to give it?

garisingh
2016-09-06 10:54
on the other hand, we could start to version individual packages as well if we can get a proper package / module structure in place for v1

garisingh
2016-09-06 10:55
in any case, this topic needs some serious thought and discussion ASAP

hgabor
2016-09-06 10:56
@garisingh okay so lets suppose we use versions you described. but what if I work on master and I want to create a new change which breaks the test and I also want to fix the test in that change such that the test passes

garisingh
2016-09-06 10:59
I think introducing breaking changes on master is ok (of course as you mention we need to fix / update the tests) once we actually get a stable version strategy in place. Once we have "stable" releases (or simply releases) we can point folks who simply want to build fabric applications to those release versions. If you want to live on the bleeding edge and use the "master" version of the fabric, you'll simply need to keep up with changes

garisingh
2016-09-06 11:01
so as long as we have say fabric v0.6 and a chaincode shim package v0.6 (the main external culprit), we'll be ok. We can version our samples, interfaces, etc

hgabor
2016-09-06 11:01
do you mean that it OK if a change intentionally breaks that test on master and then another change in fabric-test-resouces fixes it?

garisingh
2016-09-06 11:01
this will take some planning and coordination, but is certainly doable

garisingh
2016-09-06 11:01
@hgabor - yes

garisingh
2016-09-06 11:02
with the assumption that we properly version fabric-test-resources as well

hgabor
2016-09-06 11:04
wouldn't there be a solution where master could go from a clean state to a clean state? one where while developing the change in Gerrit master would be okay, and the change in Gerrit would also pass the tests and after merging the change master would also pass the tests?

garisingh
2016-09-06 11:06
Definitely

hgabor
2016-09-06 11:17
you mean there is one?

hgabor
2016-09-06 11:20
with your solution, I think the following would happen: - I upload a change to Gerrit that breaks the test - master works because it downloads the test files from some proper version. OK - my change fails because it needs a modified version of the tests. what should I do? if I modify the current version that breaks master. if I don't that makes my change fail the Jenkins tests

garisingh
2016-09-06 11:23
@hgabor - are you talking specifically about this clash we currently have with the convergence branch not really having a version?

garisingh
2016-09-06 11:24
an alternative to what I did in 901 would have been to use a separate repo for the external chaincode for the convergence branch until such time as it becomes master. The same would hold true for feature branches

hgabor
2016-09-06 11:27
@garisingh : no, I am talking about the situation when one wants to create a change on master (in Gerrit) and wants the test to pass (e.g. they need to be changed) In such a situation the tests needs to be changed separately from the ones used by master, and when the Gerrit change is merged then those new tests needs to be used by master.

garisingh
2016-09-06 11:44
Ok. Sorry - now I see what you are saying. in that case, I guess we would have to actually "version" the external resource(s) independently of the version of the fabric. So let's say that a test on master currently uses "fabric-test-resources/example_chaincode01 version 3" . You make a change which requires you to modify "example_chaincode01". So you'd need to push a new version of "fabric-test-resources/example_chaincode01 version 4". So you push that change and now in your local version of the fabric you modify the test to use "fabric-test-resources/example_chaincode01 version 4". Things pass locally and now you are ready to submit your change to master. Shouldn't this work? Basically the subtle difference is that "fabric-test-resources/example_chaincode01" is versioned independently of the fabric version

hgabor
2016-09-06 12:01
this sounds good

hgabor
2016-09-06 12:15
maybe it is a bad idea but it would also work if we used multiple subversions: branchversion.currentlyusedsubversion

garisingh
2016-09-06 12:20
on a different note (but kinda related) @cbf @ghaskins - when will we be calling the v0.6 branch an actual release (meaning we close it for merging in any new features and stabilize it)?

simon
2016-09-06 12:22
we have a v0.6 branch?

cbf
2016-09-06 12:28

garisingh
2016-09-06 12:52

ghaskins

jonathanlevi
2016-09-07 16:47
@cbf: +2 (re: versioning)

ghaskins
2016-09-07 17:02
back

ghaskins
2016-09-07 17:03
re versioning via http://gopkg.in, I am coming into the thread a bit cold but IIUC I think this is a good idea for addressing endpoints that we control (like the fabric-test-resources)

cbf
2016-09-07 17:03
I am thinking the chaincode shim, too

ghaskins
2016-09-07 17:04
+1

ghaskins
2016-09-07 17:04
yep, anything that we have that a) we control and b) must be go-gettable, a big +1 for http://gopkg.in

ghaskins
2016-09-07 17:04
the other thing we should discuss is in certain cases, “go gettable” endpoints may not be the only option

ghaskins
2016-09-07 17:05
for example, the CAR stuff in a chaintool workflow was designed to specifically address some of that ambiguity

ghaskins
2016-09-07 17:05
so, one possible avenue is to further embrace that direction

ghaskins
2016-09-07 17:07
if the coupling of CAR to CCI is seen as problematic, Im sure we could delineate them further such that the container/archive concept can be adopted independently from the interface abstraction

ghaskins
2016-09-07 17:23
@cbf i wanted to ping you about how, when the time comes, we will cut a release like v0.6.0

ghaskins
2016-09-07 17:24
it might perhaps already be understood, and if so, just stop me: but I intended the makefile to be used with that IS_RELEASE flag

ghaskins
2016-09-07 17:24
so, for any given release, I intended the following

ghaskins
2016-09-07 17:24
1) a commit that sets https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/Makefile#L41 to “true"

ghaskins
2016-09-07 17:25
2) a second commit that sets that back to false as well as bumps the version number (e.g. 0.6.0 -> 0.6.1)

ghaskins
2016-09-07 17:25
3) a tag created against (1)

ghaskins
2016-09-07 17:25
(though I am not sure how tagging will work in gerrit

ghaskins
2016-09-07 17:27
@binhn ^^^

binhn
2016-09-07 17:30
the release taxonomy only goes to 0.x, where x < 8 for developer-preview; alpha will begin with 0.8.0, 0.8.1, etc

cbf
2016-09-07 17:31
@binhn you want to start now with v0.8?

binhn
2016-09-07 17:32
we are no where near alpha, so i don’t think we should start with 0.8 now

binhn
2016-09-07 17:32
but following @ghaskins, could we do 0.6.0 ?

ghaskins
2016-09-07 17:41
@binhn: yep, hasn't been used yet

cbf
2016-09-07 17:42
we have v0.6 branch, we could follow with 0.6.1 BUT, IMO, if we are on a 1.0 path, we should have a clean break and start with 0.7 and progress

ghaskins
2016-09-07 17:44
From my perspective, we could still cut v0.6.0. We have a branch for 0.6.x development/freezing, but we never cut an actual release from it yet

ghaskins
2016-09-07 17:44
That said, if others feel the v0.6 branch point represents "0.6.0" we can certainly bump to 0.6.1

ghaskins
2016-09-07 20:38
I guess we should clarify and agree on terms. I generally wouldn't call a branch a "release" since it could be (and is in this case) a moving target

ghaskins
2016-09-07 20:39
I use tags for a specific release

ghaskins
2016-09-07 20:39
And a branch to group related point releases

ghaskins
2016-09-07 20:39
Eg v0.6.0 v0.6.1 etc

ghaskins
2016-09-07 20:40
So from that perspective, we have yet to cut 0.6.0

ghaskins
2016-09-07 20:40
We have started to isolate what will become 0.6.0 and future 0.6.x releases by curating the v0.6 branch

ghaskins
2016-09-07 20:41
But if we consider v0.6 to be out there already, that changes things

ghaskins
2016-09-07 20:42
Which is fine. I'm just not sure what merges to that branch mean specifically

ghaskins
2016-09-07 20:43
Also disappointed we didn't get to use my new versioning thing

ghaskins
2016-09-07 20:43
;)

ghaskins
2016-09-07 20:43
What do you guys think?

ghaskins
2016-09-07 20:43
@cbf @binhn

cbf
2016-09-07 20:45
Agree, a branch is NOT a release… a branch as I see it is a release in the making

cbf
2016-09-07 20:45
and yes, as patch levels

ghaskins
2016-09-07 20:48
Ok so do we agree v0.6.0 is still available as something we have yet to push? Or do we consider it out there and need to bump higher?

ghaskins
2016-09-09 18:21
@cbf I just learned something new: apparently gerrit does support “git-merge"

ghaskins
2016-09-09 18:21
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12840279/how-to-merge-the-gerrit-branch-to-another-gerrit-branch

ghaskins
2016-09-09 18:21
IIUC, if you create a non-fastforward merge record, the merge it self may be submitted for review/approval

ghaskins
2016-09-09 18:22
so, for instance, we should be able to merge master to features/convergence

cbf
2016-09-09 18:22
interesting

ghaskins
2016-09-09 18:22
(rather than submitting the same patch as a new commit

ghaskins
2016-09-09 18:22

cbf
2016-09-12 14:43
@garisingh and I were discussing (lamenting, more like;-) the current project structure

cbf
2016-09-12 14:43
we started down the path of one repo to rule them all, and a single build

cbf
2016-09-12 14:44
however, for some aspects of the project, this is starting to become problematic

cbf
2016-09-12 14:47
for instance, the SDKs introduce build dependencies that are likely better handled as independent repositories. The chaincode shim dependency is slightly compromised because while you can go get http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/etc etc/shim it pulls the entire fabric codebase with it

cbf
2016-09-12 14:48
then, as I was exploring the potential for carving out an independent binary for the CLI (distinct from the peer binary) I found that there is no way to build it without having to build rocksdb (even though there is nothing in the direct dependency tree)

cbf
2016-09-12 14:58
we are already starting down the path of extracting the SDKs (fabric-sdk-py, fabric-sdk-node, etc)

cbf
2016-09-12 14:59
here was @garisingh’s initial proposal: I was thinking we have top level repos like: 1) fabric-crypto 2) fabric-ledger 3) fabric-chaincode-shim 4) fabric-protos 5) fabric-core 6) fabric-orderer 7) fabric-peer 8) fabric-membersrvcs 9) fabric-node-sdk

cbf
2016-09-12 15:00
this will mean that stitching things together will be a bit of work, but I think in the end, will help us greatly by keeping clean interfaces

cbf
2016-09-12 15:01
it will definitely help versioning

cbf
2016-09-12 15:01
Thoughts?

cbf
2016-09-12 15:03
@ghaskins @binhn @jonathanlevi @tamas @hgabor @simon @muralisr @sheehan ^^

hgabor
2016-09-12 15:13
Good idea, and I guess there will be some kind of integration in Jenkins, yeah?

cbf
2016-09-12 15:24
yes, that's the challenging bit, but we will want to have the main project be the point of having integration

cbf
2016-09-12 15:28
note that IMO, fabric/core is bloated and I don’t think that the concept really holds for all of the bits in there

cbf
2016-09-12 15:29
I know that ledger is basically coming in with a re-boot, so maybe that work could transition from fabric/convergence branch to a separate repo

ghaskins

garisingh
2016-09-12 16:55
membersrv should be standalone package for sure. it will actually help us a lot if it is done that way.

jonathanlevi
2016-09-12 17:01
Yes, I too believe that membersrvc can/should be separate already.

jonathanlevi
2016-09-12 17:01
We should work out the API, move the stuff out of `core/`, etc.

muralisr
2016-09-12 17:09
given the strong dependency, should fabric-peer contain core, ledger ? Would core and ledger be used anywhere else ?

jonathanlevi
2016-09-12 17:23
We should work out the details. I think the first thing indeed is define the ‘boundary’ of the components and the cross-component API.

jonathanlevi
2016-09-12 17:24
I would move the interface to the ECA/TCA out of the core, and expose a layer.

jonathanlevi
2016-09-12 17:24
They should all use the same underlying primitives (e.g. Crypto)

jonathanlevi
2016-09-12 17:25
It might be easier (but we can discuss it based on use-cases, and other people’s views) to have a separation between MS and the ledger.

cbf
2016-09-12 17:41
I’m thinking that we are embarking on refactor of consensus, ledger and membersrvc

cbf
2016-09-12 17:41
we could do this gradually

cbf
2016-09-12 17:42
set up camp for the new world, and pull over what we need and if we find something needs to be common, we put in fabric-core or fabric-common or whatever

jonathanlevi
2016-09-12 17:42
Yes, I like the `common` option, over `core`

jonathanlevi
2016-09-12 17:43
It will be also be clearer in the `new` camp… so that we don’t just carry stuff that we don’t need on one hand, nor introduce extra (new) dependencies because we overlooked something...

jonathanlevi
2016-09-12 17:44
I think that defining refactoring `milestones`, will help a lot (as part of the planning).

jonathanlevi
2016-09-12 17:45
Assuring that the gradual changes converge.

2016-09-16 15:47

ghaskins
2016-09-16 15:54
so, now that ive experimented with git tags + gerrit, one possible way to do this is just trust maintainers to create tags…and tags can trigger a release

ghaskins
2016-09-16 15:55
downside is, no voting, but theres also reputational damage at stake which I think would preclude risk for the most part

ghaskins
2016-09-16 15:55
(mistakes can still be made, of course)

ghaskins
2016-09-16 15:55
alternatively, we do the filesystem thing…a file is marked to signify a release, it gets voted/merged

ghaskins
2016-09-16 15:55
and that merge kicks a CI process that tags + publishes

ghaskins
2016-09-16 15:56
i assume we want the latter

ghaskins
2016-09-16 15:56
i only bring up the former because, if we go with the latter, we should probably remove the “push annotated tag” attribute from our maintainers

ghaskins
2016-09-16 15:57
i think either workflow is doable though

ghaskins
2016-09-16 15:57
thoughts?

ghaskins
2016-09-16 15:58
either way, ill build a prototype of the file trigger today

ghaskins
2016-09-16 15:58
I already know the tag trigger works well

ry
2016-09-16 18:30
@binhn only maintainers should be able to push tags, yes, I could create a non-admin account and try to push a tag to prove it but that is our default setting

ry
2016-09-16 18:33
@cbf do you want me to delete a bunch of stuff on https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/ ?

binhn
2016-09-16 18:39
@ghaskins i thought the latter would be clearer intention and would allow others to chim in via review/vote — not too much damage on reputation :slightly_smiling_face:

ry
2016-09-16 18:41
@binhn @ghaskins I was talking to a co-worker. He suggested another repo where you would push a text file defining your tag, then the votes and merges happen there and we have a job do the actual tagging. I am reticent to pursue this because it would be Yet Another Repo and too many repos is a land mine I’ve seen projects hit too often

ghaskins
2016-09-16 18:58
Yeah I think we can achieve similar with a file in the baseimage repo

jonathanlevi
2016-09-16 19:00
A similar approach from a different perspective might be to ‘query’ using git as part of the process and to compare these to a file. The file will be merged after an approval, and if the `tag` matches what the (voted-over-)file contains the script proceeds to a release.

jonathanlevi
2016-09-16 19:01
[Thinking too about how we can avoid needing a YaR… (Yet another Repo) ;-)]

jonathanlevi
2016-09-16 19:02
That is, the ‘triggering’ event is when the tag matches the file.

ry
2016-09-16 19:02
My mental image for these repos is a MIRV warhead. ||: You think you have a handle on it, then it splits into four parts : : |

jonathanlevi
2016-09-16 19:03
Yes, the less “linear” & intuitive these are… the more prone we are to errors. I am with you.

jonathanlevi
2016-09-16 19:05
We want to automate what we can, while not incurring an insane learning curve or not understanding what’s going on, especially when there is a problem and one is tired…

jonathanlevi
2016-09-16 19:06
At same time, multiple platforms, different set-ups, several maintainers, combined code-bases, etc… requires some work/planning/thinking [& some `/self-torturing` ;-)]

garisingh
2016-09-16 19:12
While we don't want to add too much overhead and I agree automation and some level of "trust" are fine, we really do need to add some "maturity" to how things get done in this project. For example, take a look at https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Release+Process

ry
2016-09-16 19:20
as your ~attorney~ release engineer, I wholeheartedly agree

cbf
2016-09-16 19:41

cbf

ghaskins
2016-09-19 15:19
im starting to think we should _not_ build any fabric components by default in the vagrant-up provisioning process

ghaskins
2016-09-19 15:20
the issue as I see it is: we are building some subset today: we assume that this is what most users will want, but if we get it wrong, they might be waiting for nothing

ghaskins
2016-09-19 15:20
so, why gate the “success” criteria of the devenv on building…just let the user drive what they want once its available

ghaskins
2016-09-19 15:20
thoughts?

2016-09-19 15:40

@cbf: the proposed rule change is in place in lf-sandbox if you want to see it live. Committers can push merge commits for review in the style discussed above (git merge —no-ff; git commit —amend -s)

ry
2016-09-26 21:27
yes. the only change is that maintainers will be allowed to upload merges for review. this will make keeping branches up with master easier. however it will require more diligence on the part of maintainers to prevent reverse or mis-targeted merges

cbf which projects should we have this on? I assume only fabric to start, since it’s really the only project with velocity?

2016-09-26 21:35

ry
2016-09-26 22:20

cbf
2016-09-27 20:34
@ghaskins you had some concerns about the name of the ‘fabric-node-sdk’ image. I get your point. It really is an image for consuming the sdk and writing applications. Of course, when you think about this going forward, there are some options to consider as to how developers consume fabric. In my fevered imagination, I envisage that developers will work in a typical containerized manner, pulling images to their laptop, running them and exec’ing into them to develop. Hence this really could be considered an SDK container image - for node. Now, the challenge then becomes as we add more chaincode support, then you have combinatorial challenge. Node SDK + Go chaincode, Node + Java chaincode, Java SDK + Java chaincode, Java SDK + Solidity, etc etc etc

cbf
2016-09-27 20:35
I am thinking that we are mostly concerned at this point with v0.6 and that really has just a stable nodeSDK and go chaincode, all of which are in the fabric-sdk-node image.

cbf
2016-09-27 20:37
I suppose we could have fabric—sdk-<sdk lang>-<chaincode lang> available for developers

cbf
2016-09-27 20:38
however, at this point, I wonder if we should just call it fabric-sdk and be done with it for v0.6 and work out something grander for when we have the collection of various sdk and chaincode options

cbf
2016-09-27 20:38
@garisingh @binhn @muralisr @jzhang

cbf
2016-09-27 20:38
thoughts?

jzhang
2016-09-27 20:38
has joined #fabric-maintainers

binhn
2016-09-27 20:42
nodeSDK has a disadvantage later on as no nodejs chaincode — hard to imagine someone using javasdk and go-chaincode

muralisr
2016-09-27 20:42
@cbf without understanding or going into all ramifications… there’s something simple and elegant about “one” fabric-sdk containing everything (“eclipse” comes to mind…) and users user different things from it

binhn
2016-09-27 20:43
the sdk encapsulates the dev env for the intended language https://docs.google.com/document/d/1R5RtIBMW9fZpli37E5Li5_Q9ve3BnQ4q3gWmGZj6Sv4/edit#heading=h.z6ne0og04bp5

muralisr
2016-09-27 20:43
right, @binh… I was thinking more about an organization within the sdk

binhn
2016-09-27 20:44
@jzhang might have to think about providing nodejs chaincode

cbf
2016-09-27 20:49
@muralisr one fabric-sdk could work, but it would be bloated

cbf
2016-09-27 20:50
think that devs would want minimal surface area for deploying

muralisr
2016-09-27 20:51
true, however easier to maintain and package…. don’t know how much bloating can be tolerated ? eclipse keep coming to mind :slightly_smiling_face:

jzhang
2016-09-27 20:52
@ghaskins @cbf the fabric-node-sdk image is just a “Getting Started” component, I wouldn’t think it’d be part of a typical developer set up for day-in-day-out node.js development. this purpose of this image is so that new comers to the platform can get an end-to-end experience with minimal install dependencies, aka Docker only.

cbf
2016-09-27 20:52
so we could rename fabric-starter-kit

jzhang
2016-09-27 20:54
for a typical developer set up for daily activities, i would like to get to a place where both chaincode and application development can be done in a native environment. so whether it’s GO or Java for chaincode, or node.js/python/Java for using the SDK, you’d do it in your native host environment directly

cbf
2016-09-27 20:55
well, yes, but we aren’t there

jzhang
2016-09-27 20:55
+1 for renaming to “fabric-starter-kit"

jzhang
2016-09-27 20:56
that’s right, the sticking point is separating out the shim

ghaskins
2016-09-27 20:56
I like starter kit +1

ghaskins
2016-09-27 20:56
Way more descriptive

cbf
2016-09-27 21:26
ok, I’ll rename, add the other related files and repush my change

understood, but I look at the others and it seems they were all V-1

simon
2016-10-04 11:54
best draw what package depends on what

simon
2016-10-04 11:54
to prevent import loops

simon
2016-10-04 11:55
i guess 7 is needed by 1,2,3,4,5, maybe 6

2016-10-04 11:55

hgabor
2016-10-04 11:55

2016-10-04 11:55

simon
2016-10-04 11:55

hgabor
2016-10-04 11:55

simon
2016-10-04 11:55

hgabor
2016-10-04 11:56

simon
2016-10-04 11:56

simon
2016-10-04 11:56
so that you don't have to write your own

simon
2016-10-04 11:57
likewise i'd expect (2) to provide the routines to talk to the CA

hgabor
2016-10-04 12:04
yeah, you are right, AB (from 1) ) is needed by 3, 4, 5

hgabor
2016-10-04 12:05

hgabor
2016-10-04 12:07

hgabor
2016-10-04 12:26

jonathanlevi
2016-10-04 12:53

hgabor
2016-10-04 12:54

jonathanlevi
2016-10-04 12:58

jonathanlevi
2016-10-04 12:59

jonathanlevi
2016-10-04 12:59
It’s OK - not impossible. But @simon raised a good point…

hgabor
2016-10-04 13:02
@binhn will send out a proposal with these repos

jeffgarratt
2016-10-04 14:14
I am on the don't do it side

jeffgarratt
2016-10-04 14:16
Not sure we have the same mechanisms available as say Java to manage the dependency system

hgabor
2016-10-05 08:43
@jeffgarratt do you mean something like this? http://labix.org/gopkg.in

garisingh
2016-10-05 11:13
we have been thinking about / playing around with using http://gopkg.in in order to version packages where it makes sense. the most obvious one(s) tend to be the interfaces which "clients" use - e.g. chaincode shim, GRPC APIs, etc. Chaincode shim has been the biggest trouble maker to date. Now http://gopkg.in follow a model where you do not break interfaces within a release stream only when doing a major version release. For example, `go get http://gopkg.in/mastersingh24/mypackage.v0` will be pull the latest branch/tag form `http://github.com/mastersingh24/mypackage` which matches the the form `v0.N.N`. If we change the interface, you need to bump the version to `v1.N.N`

simon
2016-10-05 11:19
sounds good?

hgabor
2016-10-05 11:53
it can work

ghaskins
2016-10-05 12:18
@garisingh I like the overall plan, but I would encourage specific tags rather than ones that allow it to float

garisingh
2016-10-05 12:19
Agreed

ghaskins
2016-10-05 12:19
my only other concern is the long term reliability of http://gopkg.in…we saw it go down a few weeks back

ghaskins
2016-10-05 12:19
i wonder if there is a hosting option, e.g. http://gopkg.hyperledger.org

ghaskins
2016-10-05 12:20
not saying we would be more reliable than http://gopkg.in, but at least we control our destiny :wink:

garisingh
2016-10-05 12:20
@arnaud suggested we might want to see if LF could host a version

garisingh
2016-10-05 12:21
Always best when you can blame yourself

ghaskins
2016-10-05 12:21
right

jonathanlevi
2016-10-05 12:34
Hi Jeff, I just don’t want to miss anything. When you say:

jonathanlevi
2016-10-05 12:34
… what exactly do you mean?

jonathanlevi
2016-10-05 12:34
You suggest not to separate to components/modules?

jonathanlevi
2016-10-05 12:35
Just to say that I am OK with the ("non-exisitng”) dependencies injection which Golang provides…(pardon the triple negative here)...

jonathanlevi
2016-10-05 12:36
… and some of these modules are certainly not stateless. That’s also true/known, etc. But I am happy to hear/discuss more.

hgabor
2016-10-05 12:42
btw what do you think about the connections between the parts that simon pointed out? e.g. will we have to implement xyz proto client multiple times, or will we have that in proto repo?

hgabor
2016-10-05 13:44
((( maintainers: please review these https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1467/ https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1271/ )))

jeffgarratt
2016-10-05 13:44
@jonathanlevi I am unclear as to the advantage of this effort, or what problem it is solving. We do have separate components/modules. What seems to be being discussed here is separation into different repos. I do not see these as analogous.

jeffgarratt
2016-10-05 13:48
It would be of interest to me to see how the workflow is improved for the developer who would be the consumer of this proposal.

jeffgarratt
2016-10-05 13:55
To some extent the original choice of golang was meant to narrow the choices wrt to module organization, to obviate the issues associated with modularity (see Jigsaw and Java for example). Thus limiting our options, and not incurring the complexity associated with attempting such a feat, at the cost of development aesthetics (aka it aint pretty, but it's simple).

jeffgarratt
2016-10-05 13:55
Golang was predicated on the tenet of limiting your options.

hgabor
2016-10-05 14:01
@jeffgarratt the developer would face less code (easier to understand), the source would be more organized and the components would have a well-defined API

ghaskins
2016-10-05 14:04
I understand where @jeffgarratt is coming from, and I would add one more challenge to splitting things up

ghaskins
2016-10-05 14:04
i would classify it as “the branching problem"

ghaskins
2016-10-05 14:04
that is, things in one repo are naturally branchable…when you split them up, this becomes more awkward (consider parallel efforts for v0.6 and convergence

jeffgarratt
2016-10-05 14:05
@hgabor At what cost? I would assert that all of the above can be achieved by reorganizing the code in the fabric repo, (wrt less code, if the developer focuses simply on a module, the same result is attained)

ghaskins
2016-10-05 14:05
you have to manage the branching with version numbers carefully, and it can be awkward

hgabor
2016-10-05 14:05
maybe a heavy reorganization would also do it, no doubt

ghaskins
2016-10-05 14:05
that said, I am for the split and heres why

ghaskins
2016-10-05 14:06
if we were talking about purely go modules, the argument to stay as a monolith repo would be stronger, but we arent

ghaskins
2016-10-05 14:06
node sdk, and java shim are good examples: they are super awkward to be in something considered\ a go-module in certain contexts

ry
2016-10-05 14:06
We will soon have NEXUS available

ry
2016-10-05 14:06
If this informs your discussion

ghaskins
2016-10-05 14:07
(ty @ry, that is good news indeed)

ghaskins
2016-10-05 14:07
but i will also point out that we have run into some issues with even the pure go space

ghaskins
2016-10-05 14:07
having the golang shim be under the fabric project, which has its own vendor, has been a problem

ghaskins
2016-10-05 14:08
so, i think I am in favor of at least seeing things like sdks and shims as separate repos

ghaskins
2016-10-05 14:08
i dont have an opinion on the finer grained parts of the conversation, like splitting out orderer or membersrvc

ghaskins
2016-10-05 14:11
@jeffgarratt does have a point that at least some aspects of the problem could be addressed with code reorganization within the single repo

jonathanlevi
2016-10-05 18:18
@ghaskins, @jeffgarratt I agree. I would argue that the code reorganization within the repo is a critical milestone (which is needed either way).

jonathanlevi
2016-10-05 18:18
I think that would be a good start.

jonathanlevi
2016-10-05 18:20
I also believe that separating the functionality (even logically) so that the boundaries are clearer… where one can see what services/APIs each component consumes/provides and how… is what we need.

jonathanlevi
2016-10-05 18:21
___ Vendoring in go is a good topic, but one that we should resolve regardless too.

jonathanlevi
2016-10-05 18:23
I’m more about separating to components/modules (that are more than just directories) where we include whatever is missing (and by that cross the boundaries)… I argue that this is where the bulk of the work lies. The rest should be a lot simpler (and hopefully, will be more convincing/appealing to you @jeffgarratt and others) once the first step is complete).

jonathanlevi
2016-10-05 18:25
Or otherwise, maybe after restructuring the code so nicely, we’ll learn that it’s good enough. But still, it’s a good goal to have, especially when people promote the pluggable architecture. I think that more/better componentization is needed.

jonathanlevi
2016-10-05 18:26
— Hmmm. Such a long answer…. Maybe I should start a blog? Nah, maybe not :wink: —

hgabor
2016-10-05 19:44
I support the code reorganization to separate components

hgabor
2016-10-05 19:44
We should have a plan for that. Do you think we should do it in small steps or with one big commit?

ry
2016-10-05 20:16
@hgabor: flag days are good.

hgabor
2016-10-05 20:20
Chicken is my fav

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 10:41
That’s a good point. I’m torn between the following 2 options:

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 10:42
Option 1: All it all in one big/huge commit, with no new tests - but making sure that most of existing tests fail, disabling all lint checks, no sign-offs, tabs, spaces, random licensing info (if at all), and not deploying anything to any CI/build or other online repos, hopefully breaking the preferred/agreed-upon versioning scheme.

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 10:44
Option 2: Gradually, using several iterations, planning, coordinating - also in writing, breaking bigger tasks to sprints, letting everybody know what to expect, sharing the work, added more unit-tests and slowly cross-component integration tests, improving coverage, code-quality and making more people feel-good.

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 10:45
If option 2 does not come across as the preferred way, then I’d beg to differ :wink:

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 10:45
----

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 10:46
In short: definitely in small steps. Though some parts might be a bit easier than others, so we (can) schedule such changes accordingly.

ry
2016-10-06 10:47
jonathanlevi if I understand the scope of changes, let me propose this to be torn apart: start _n_ repos that are basically copies of the one repo, removing and reworking until we have the right number of subsets in good shape

garisingh
2016-10-06 10:47
@jonathanlevi @hgabor - sadly, my hope had been that this is the way things were being done in the convergence branch - and I think this is partially true for things like the orderer and ledger components

garisingh
2016-10-06 10:48
assuming you stick with one repo to start with ^^^^ (although I think that membersrvc should actually be a separate project - because there should be ZERO dependency between the fabric and a particular implementation of membersrvc if you do that part right)

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 10:49
I totally agree re: membersrvc + it might be easy(ier) too to do so for the chaincode.

garisingh
2016-10-06 10:49
I simply can't understand why we are struggling with getting a base project / structure in place for the "skeleton" end to end flow. I know people disagree on throwing stuff out, etc, but that has always been my take

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 10:50
Yes, I don’t understand that either. In general, my take is that throwing away code, especially in Incubation is GOOD ! It will be so much more expensive (if possible at all) to do so later.

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 10:52
There is a increasingly growing number of vendors looking and working with fabric already. The sooner we make `such` changes, the better.

garisingh
2016-10-06 10:52
My personal theory / preference for v1 has always been basically start fresh with the basic outline / skeleton for the end to end flow (stubbing / mocking pieces as required for communication between components) and then literally cutting and pasting previous code when appropriate. I believe this is what @simon did with the sBFT stuff and the ordering service (solo and kafka) have been built as nice self-contained components as well

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 10:52
___ What I was adding earlier though is that we do also need to restructure the code (that core/… part which is “shared” still)

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 10:53
— Nothing’s really “free”. It requires some work, sweat, breaking, fixing, etc...

garisingh
2016-10-06 10:53
agreed - especially because some of it should't be shared :wink:

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 10:53
Cycles/iterations

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 10:55
Don’t want to swim against the stream here, but I’m still all for LESS exotics features, more NATIVE support for the main use-cases.

ry
2016-10-06 10:55
the happy path should be well trodden, yes

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 10:55
We can/should have others extending/building on top… should such features be needed. Stronger foundations are needed, IMHO.

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 10:57
@ry: exactly. The happy-path, the positive-flow, etc…. exactly. The main use-cases should be really intuitively supported/tested/documented/etc. Nobody has an infinite amount of resources…

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 11:01
— And believe me, I’m now at the end of an almost 4 weeks long "round-the-globe-tour" of various BC technologies - evaluating/viewing so many ‘sexy’ blockchain features, and most of them are still in `alpha`. It’s good to `innovate` but we should also work to `stabilize`. Especially if we are really focusing on enterprise deployments, etc. —

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 11:01
Maybe I should start signing my emails/reviews with `LEMS`

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 11:02
`L`ess `E`xotic, `M`ore `S`tability.

ry
2016-10-06 11:03
everyone wants to write Angular, nobody wants to write COBOL, but I’d be willing to be the majority of the world’s money is still underpinned by the latter

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 11:04
I hear you.

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 11:05
Though I think that Go, especially the latest, is really cutting edge… nice/fun features, good community, etc. We do have a nice tool/stack here.

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 11:06
We really need more tests, more documentation, more use-cases presented plainly etc. and these will be/are needed regardless of language/platform.

jonathanlevi
2016-10-06 11:08
BTW: @ry We should talk about http://www.blockchainweek2016.org… it highlighted exactly what you wrote above…. still, I’d give more weight to stability even if it is just for a few months (or done in parallel).

muralisr
2016-10-06 12:02
I might have missed something (or getting out of topic)… once convergence goes to master, there is no turning back to old ways of doing stuff. The only thing we’d then have that limps along is the skeletal. Given that the very first thing is, (1) is it ok to merge convergence first with just the skeletal and nothing else so we get to master or (2) we take a bit of time to identify other things to go into convergence to make it more functional and then merge ?

muralisr
2016-10-06 12:04
BTW, the thing I wanted to do next is complete the ledgernext integration with the chaincode framework and make all the chaincode unit tests run with ledgernext… that could fall into the category of “things to do in convergence before moving to master” as it would help validate the move

garisingh
2016-10-06 12:10
@muralisr - so have you documented somewhere how to run the end to end skeleton in convergence?

muralisr
2016-10-06 12:11
@garisingh there is instructions in https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1385/ comments

muralisr
2016-10-06 12:11
I can write more

hgabor
2016-10-06 12:18
am I right that we are aiming for one clean repo now?

ry
2016-10-06 12:19
hgabor I thought we were going for seven repos, did that change?

hgabor
2016-10-06 12:21
>jonathanlevi >8:18 PM @ghaskins, @jeffgarratt I agree. I would argue that the code reorganization within the >repo is a critical milestone (which is needed either way). >8:18 I think that would be a good start.

hgabor
2016-10-06 12:22
I guess he meant that the first step should be code reorg in our current repo (and if needed we can introduce new repos THEN). and I agree

muralisr
2016-10-06 12:23
evetually we’ll have to do the repo split (and it could be 7 or around 7)… but probably baby steps with just move from convergence to master in 1 repo ?

hgabor
2016-10-06 12:24
would we have to do the repo split if we had a clean repo with separated components?

ry
2016-10-06 12:25
hgabor the goal, as I understood it, was to let people focus on the parts of the project where they had the most to offer, without having to pay attention to the other parts

ry
2016-10-06 12:26
it lets people iterate on one part quickly without requiring sign off from other maintainers, and without inflating the maintainer list

ry
2016-10-06 12:26
once the parts are decomposed, each edge will be a well-defined API and as such things become independent and pluggable

hgabor
2016-10-06 12:27
yeah but can't they focus if the repo is well-organized and the component borders are well-defined etc?

ry
2016-10-06 12:28
I’m thinking in particular about @yacovm’s work getting stuck in limbo due to timezones and not enough committers in that code area

ghaskins
2016-10-06 12:28
one of the things I think we should ideally achieve is to at least clean things up so that the modularization mechanisms actually work properly

ghaskins
2016-10-06 12:29
for instance “go get http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/core/chaincode/shim” should be something that works, but its super awkward today

ghaskins
2016-10-06 12:29
for one, its subject to the fabric.git/vendoring, which is not necessarily the right context

ghaskins
2016-10-06 12:30
second, it also pulls in other things like nodejs and java code, the devenv scripts, etc

ghaskins
2016-10-06 12:32
i am not sure if someone can make both repo organization and go happy at the same time though

ghaskins
2016-10-06 12:32
go is a little weird in this sense in that the repo is also the packaging

ghaskins
2016-10-06 12:33
for example: both golang and java shims are “shims”, so you would be inclined to organize them accordingly…maybe fabric.git/shims/[go,java]

ghaskins
2016-10-06 12:34
but that creates a weird go package as a result (http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/shims/go)

ghaskins
2016-10-06 12:34
or maybe that is fine, I don’t know

ghaskins
2016-10-06 12:35
but the main point is that what makes the most sense from a code org perspective gets harder to align with what makes the most sense from a modular package perspective as we add more and more stuff to the same repo

ghaskins
2016-10-06 12:35
so, from this perspective, I am leaning towards things like the shims and sdks to have their own repos

muralisr
2016-10-06 12:39
@ghaskins as long as versioning doesn’t become hairy… most people want to use and a smaller percentage contribute. I can see merit in the separate repo though. In any case I’d think - for expediency - we should do convergence merge to master first and then work on repos ?

ghaskins
2016-10-06 12:40
that makes sense to me

ghaskins
2016-10-06 12:41
@muralisr but yes, versioning can be more challenging with extra repos, agreed

ghaskins
2016-10-06 12:41
specifically when concurrent streams exist

ghaskins
2016-10-06 12:41
e.g. v0.6 AND convergence

muralisr
2016-10-06 12:41
right that’s what I was thinking of

ghaskins
2016-10-06 12:41
to me, that is the biggest downside

muralisr
2016-10-06 12:42
yes again!

muralisr
2016-10-06 12:44
have to get ready for work… will be online soon

hgabor
2016-10-06 12:48
anyways, I would prefer having 1 repo with separate components (in separate directories) and a clean structure. And interfaces for communication between them.

ghaskins
2016-10-06 13:12

ghaskins
2016-10-06 13:12

ghaskins
2016-10-06 13:12

ry
2016-10-06 14:51

ghaskins

ry
2016-10-06 15:11

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:11

2016-10-06 15:11

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:11

ry
2016-10-06 15:12

ry
2016-10-06 15:12

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:12
I think that is true, in general, but the way I see it there is a topology like v0.6->master->convergence

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:13
i.e. convergence is a superset of master which is superset of v0.6

ry
2016-10-06 15:13
ok.

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:13
so, at some point, master and convergence diverged, but I dont think that means we want to discard the work that went into master per se

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:13
(for instance, I did all the baseimage updates in master

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:14
case in point, master uses baseimage v0.1.0 (the new CI stuff) where as v0.6 and convergence still use the old v0.0.11

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:14
so, I want to make sure we retain the “supetset” nature

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:14
it could be I am one of the few who is contributing to master though, I am not sure

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:15
in the ideal world, they wouldn’t have diverged at all, but we only had the merge capability added recently as one of a few steps to prevent the divergence

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:16
well, obviously the point is to diverge, heh

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:16
i mean w.r.t. the superset nature

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:16
convergence should be superset, not orthogonal

ry
2016-10-06 15:17
I suppose we could do cherry picks of specific work on master to move over important stuff

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:17

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:18
(im not sure a fully automated merge is a good idea, but we can at least have something monitoring the condition)

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:18
yes, to your point, there could very well be stuff in master that is no longer relevant

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:18
I know at least the baseimage stuff should be in convergence, but I dont know about the other changes

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:19
personally, id probably feel better about a merge rather than a cherry pick though…less likely to miss something important

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:19
depends on how much work it is to resolve vs how much value we think went into master, I suppose

ry
2016-10-06 15:19
a cherry pick should be reasonably atomic

ry
2016-10-06 15:19
sure.

ghaskins
2016-10-06 15:20

ghaskins

ghaskins

cbf
2016-10-07 15:00
so, TL;DR: I caught up to yesterday but then saw things start to fall apart

cbf
2016-10-07 15:01
I think we need to pursue the multiple repos gradually

cbf
2016-10-07 15:02
some could be fresh start as Gari suggests, and others can be decomposition/refactoring of the current entangled package structure (I am already hitting this big time with the Go SDK/CLI

cbf
2016-10-07 15:02
we need protos on its own with no external dependencies from other modules

cbf
2016-10-07 15:02
currently there are some dependencies with some stuff in peer/common and core/comm and so forth

cbf
2016-10-07 15:03
then, we refactor the dependent components to pull in the fabric-protos package as external dependency

cbf
2016-10-07 15:04
lather, rinse repeat - gradually build up to where we need to get (@hgabor’s #2 which @jonathanlevi supported and I certainly support)

cbf
2016-10-07 15:04
one big commit will be almost impossible

cbf
2016-10-07 15:04
could be that every new repo just starts as @ry suggested as a copy of master and deletes stuff that isn’t necessary

cbf
2016-10-07 15:05
we do need a solid proposal that organizes what goes where

cbf
2016-10-07 15:05
to avoid the circular import problem

cbf
2016-10-07 15:05
so, who is working on the proposal?

hgabor
2016-10-10 15:06
everybody: as you know I have this commit chain: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/941/ it is a little bit inconsistent now as it reflects two different ideas (inconsistent = code not rebased because it needs manual merge). which do you prefer? 1) have an error handling 'framework' similar to the current way of error handling where one can create his/her own error using Errorf("anything") (errors.Errorf instead of fmt.Errorf) 2) have one that supports multiple languages but with predefined errors read from a json file where there is a mapping of ERROR_CODEs, languages and error messages Please tell me what you think.

hgabor

hgabor
2016-10-11 10:17
@cbf linked me some good globalization framework

hgabor
2016-10-11 10:17

hgabor
2016-10-11 11:39
> @hgabor I believe one to one mapping between error codes and error messages would not be possible as one error code might result in different error messages. For example, AUTH_ERROR might be caused by an invalid password, an unknown user name or a locked account and you might want to give a slightly different message in each case. (AUTH_ERROR is just an example, some error codes will have only one possible message but others might have more than one possible messages). Error codes should represent a broader category of errors not individual error messages

hgabor
2016-10-11 11:39
by @maltaf

cbf
2016-10-11 11:45
@hgabor i18n4go https://github.com/maximilien/i18n4go was developed for Cloud Foundry by an IBMer.

hgabor
2016-10-11 11:59
@cbf that's it, thanks :slightly_smiling_face:

ghaskins
2016-10-11 20:20
all: in the interest of coordinating effort and reducing duplication, fyi that @muralisr and I started work late last week to attempt to synchronize the master and feature/convergence branches

ghaskins
2016-10-11 20:20
first phase is identifying the patches that went into master since convergence was cut…this is nearly complete

ghaskins
2016-10-11 20:21
second phase will be to go through the list and either discard or apply the patch to convergence, depending on relevance

ghaskins
2016-10-11 20:22
the end result of this would be the convergence branch would minimally be caught up on any divergent changes between the two branches

ghaskins
2016-10-11 20:22
it would also mean we could opt to merge convergence back on top of master, at our discretion

ghaskins
2016-10-11 20:23

weeds
2016-10-13 20:05
has joined #fabric-maintainers

hgabor
2016-10-14 13:37
Maintainers, I would like to know what you think: Error handling (again). We want to have a solution with multi language support, and some level of hierarchy for errors. (We also want optional call stack support but this is OK.) Now, I see two possible solutions for this: 1) see https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/941/ It has an error descriptor file (errors.json) with errors which are hierarchical, and consist of a return code plus a reason code. A return code is e.g. the originating module/package/component (e.g. ledger). A reason code is something lower level e.g. Genesis_not_found. These errors have a map of languages + error messages. In JSON this looks like: { "1" : { "1" : { "en" : "Error message" } } } With this approach a developer instantiates an error using e.g. the following code: errors.Error(LEDGER, GENESIS_NOT_FOUND) where LEDGER and GENESIS... are constants defined in errors.go (framework module) and they are numbers. The only problem I see with this approach is that we have to maintain the relation between the constants defined in errors.go and the JSON in errors.json. We should be sure that 1) there is an error from the JSON for every constant and a constant for every error from the JSON 2) users do not use wrong pairs, non-existing or ad-hoc defined errors etc... 2) we could have a pre-build source generation process (like in case of protos and make protos) where we would generate a go file containing 1 error struct for every return-reason pair defined by the JSON. (not many files but one with all the structs). e.g. we could use this: https://github.com/ChimeraCoder/gojson problem is whether we should commit the generated go file, when to regenerate it, how to do the build etc etc something like in case of protos.

n.ohagan
2016-10-14 13:56
has joined #fabric-maintainers

hgabor
2016-10-14 14:06
@garisingh @cbf @ghaskins @jonathanlevi and others :slightly_smiling_face:

n.ohagan
2016-10-14 14:11
@n.ohagan has left the channel

muralisr
2016-10-14 14:34
@hgabor after we merge master and convergence, we can expect lot of activity… it would be better to get the error framework in so developers can instructed to use it from get-go and maintainers to catch if submissions don’t use the framework… so whatever we decide better be soon so as to unblock you

muralisr
2016-10-14 14:38
I think having a jason based approach to capture {maincode , subcode, language (def. english)} like you describe is reasonable… perhaps also have (1) with instructions for use (2) example of its use in some package and (3) playback showing it in action ?

hgabor
2016-10-14 19:06
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/941 added some simple tests and examples. will add more info to the wiki

hgabor
2016-10-14 19:06
and will record a playback

hgabor
2016-10-14 19:06
this is out of date: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/977/10 I won't fix it, will create a new for examples

hgabor
2016-10-14 19:40
https://wiki.hyperledger.org/error-handling

hgabor
2016-10-14 19:41
I owe you with some real life examples and a playback

2016-10-16 00:44
@garisingh there were two issues: 1) it was merged rather than rebased so the ordinality is at best confusing

ghaskins
2016-10-16 00:44

ghaskins
2016-10-16 00:45
the second issue is that the companion merge (1413) should go with it

ghaskins
2016-10-16 00:45
or we run the risk of having more than one build masquerade as a release

ghaskins
2016-10-16 00:45
not a big deal, i think I salvaged it

ghaskins
2016-10-16 01:13
to be clear, there were no explicit merges pushed here

ghaskins
2016-10-16 01:13
the merge I was referring to is the default way gerrit handles accepting any CR

ghaskins
2016-10-16 01:14
normally I would have rebased CR 1411 on to the HEAD of v0.6, and applied to tag directly to the commit

ghaskins
2016-10-16 01:15
but because it wasnt rebased, gerrit merged it…. I think I can more or less achieve the same effect by simply just tagging the merge record instead of the commit that set IS_RELEASE = true

ghaskins
2016-10-16 01:16
I do not anticipate any fallout from this overall, other than someone may be confused when doing forensics on the history

ghaskins
2016-10-16 01:18
@ghaskins uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ghaskins/F2PSVCUPQ/git_log____oneline.xml and commented: Compare this history to the one displayed graphically above

ghaskins
2016-10-16 01:18
according to this history, it _looks_ like release v0.6.1-preview was done on line 15, and all the work that was submitted on lines 3-14 came after

ghaskins
2016-10-16 01:19
this is ordered by the date the patch was written, but not the date that the patch actually takes effect

ghaskins
2016-10-16 01:19
line 15 doesnt really take effect until line 2 when the CR was merged

ghaskins
2016-10-16 01:20
like I mentioned, normally what I would do is I would have rebased 2d75cbc on top of 7123f77 and then tagged that commit directly

ghaskins
2016-10-16 01:21
instead, in this case, I ended up tagging e728c5c

jonathanlevi
2016-10-16 04:35
One of the things we should look into is what happened here: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1607/

jonathanlevi
2016-10-16 04:36
These 3 failing reverify and then suddenly the deluge of `success`

jonathanlevi
2016-10-16 04:37
We have some others… but this one in particular is something that made many of us raise our eyebrows.

muralisr
2016-10-16 12:53
@ghaskins I think some of the confusion was because of ChaincodeInvokeChaincode failure in DEV env - due to developers having files in that folder (“log” file, “chaincode_example02” exe etc) which were leftovers from some previous runs. This caused users to “fix” it by changing the hash to make it work in the dev env and submitting it. This of course caused it to fail in CI. Later it was reverted… when dust settled down CI began to work again but of course the DEV failed again when chaincode_example02 folder was not cleaned up.

muralisr
2016-10-16 12:54
that’s the one error I know of… there may be others. Went into details so we can avoid this in future

ghaskins
2016-10-16 14:37
FYI, I dont think we are out of the woods

ghaskins
2016-10-17 13:00

ghaskins
2016-10-17 13:00
when do you plan on having facilities in the production flow?

ramesh
2016-10-17 13:03
We have these jobs in production flow but without tag based release.. I am missing `git-parameter` in JJB for tag based releases.

ghaskins
2016-10-17 13:19
long term, im not sure if its needed

ghaskins
2016-10-17 13:20
i envision the pipeline eventually might be something where an intermediate stage of a -merge job pushes an artifact to nexus, and the -release stage pushes the nexus artifact to the external repo

ghaskins
2016-10-17 13:20
in which case, using a git tag isnt necessarily the reference point

ghaskins
2016-10-17 13:20
that said, you might still need a more expressive interface to realize this than you have now

ghaskins
2016-10-17 13:20
so, my question to the CI team is: is JJB overly restrictive?

ghaskins
2016-10-17 13:21
should we be doing something else?

ghaskins
2016-10-17 13:21
related: what do other teams use for dockerhub-like pipelines?

ramesh
2016-10-17 13:26
It is not restrictive.. I am working on that but for we can use work around approach created in sandbox environment.. but yes, for long term we definitely should have a automation deploy process

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-10-18 02:59

2016-10-18 03:00

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-10-18 03:01

ghaskins
2016-10-18 03:01

ry
2016-10-18 03:02

ghaskins
2016-10-18 03:03

ghaskins
2016-10-18 03:03

ghaskins

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:10
well, i think the concern before was that the merge-perm was granted to all maintainers

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:10
and git can be tricky, so we had weirdness in the v0.6 branch as a result

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:10
its not entirely clear if that situation was allowed because of the merge perm, but its not clear it wasnt either

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:10
e.g. it was a mistake, but it might have been caught if the permissions were tighter

muralisr
2016-10-18 15:11

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:11
anyway, in an abundance of caution, we turned off the feature again

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:11
oh yeah, if we go the temporary route

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:11

muralisr
2016-10-18 15:12
yes ? I was thinking that would work ?

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:12
i think so…with the caveat that I do not know how much of a PITA it would be for ry

ry
2016-10-18 15:13
I’m just going to enable it for all committers instead of setting up a new ldap group

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:13
with the assumption that its trivial, the proposal could be a) ry turns on the perm for maintainers, b) maintainer pushes the merge CR for review, c) ry turns it off again

ry
2016-10-18 15:13
I trust you all to behave, and I think turning it off doesn’t buy much, but I’ll abide by your wishes

ry
2016-10-18 15:14
s/committers/maintainers

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:14
its not a lack of trust, its just easy to make a mistake

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:14
but yeah, ultimately the lack of the feature is really limiting in what we can do for branching

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:15
so, I think if given no choice, we are better with care/auditing than the lack of ability

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:15
thats my thoughts

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:15
but again, i dont want this to be unilateral

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:15
id prefer everyone chime in

muralisr
2016-10-18 15:17
+1 for above decision (and I’ll stay away from convergence branch till I hear from @ghaskins and @ry

muralisr
2016-10-18 15:20
@ry …` I think turning it off doesn’t buy much, ` … I sense a hole in my understanding. I’d have thought after turning it off we are back to biz as usual ?

ry
2016-10-18 15:23
it’s belt-and-suspenders. Merges might be relatively rare on this project (I don’t know how many feature branches may end up existing) but on other projects we leave this on and maintainers take care when doing a merge.

ry
2016-10-18 15:24
if merges become more common (if feature branches become more common) this won’t scale, obviously

ry
2016-10-18 15:25
the issue that we ran in to is that cbf was on branch a and pushed to branch b and merged. there doesn’t appear to be anything I can do to prevent that, because gerrit can’t tell an errant push from a legitimate merge

ry
2016-10-18 15:25
so we’re using this roadblock to prevent these sneaky inverse merges, which is reasonable

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:26
where is everyone today?

ry
2016-10-18 15:26
anyway. merges for maintainers are now enabled, take care

ry
2016-10-18 15:27
s/take care/take care to push to the branch you really want/

ry
2016-10-18 15:27
not “take care I’m out of here for the day"

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:27
right

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:27
heh

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:27
“good luck with that” <drops the mic>

ry
2016-10-18 15:28
yeah, not quite what I intended :slightly_smiling_face:

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:28
heh, i understood what you meant fwiw

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:29
well, i guess since i know it still needs to pass through a 2+2 gate, ill push the CR out there so we can at least start to review/test it

ry
2016-10-18 15:29
I see merges as part of the everyday workflow on other projects - like, literally every single day - so this project is in a weird stage right now

ghaskins
2016-10-18 15:29
but I def would like the other maintainers to weigh in on the matter

ghaskins

jyellick
2016-10-20 17:13
Just a quick check on merge policy, we need two +2s to merge, then can any maintainer submit? Or should someone not involved in the +2-ing do so?

ry
2016-10-20 17:14
current practice seems to be the second person to +2 a change merges it most frequently, but that is merely an observation of mine

jyellick
2016-10-20 17:14
Great, thanks @ry

cbf
2016-10-20 20:57
@hgabor GWS!

cbf
2016-10-20 20:58
@jyellick usually the second +2 should push the submit but I have observed that sometimes people don’t and so I go in and clean-up occasionally

cbf
2016-10-20 20:58
technically, we just need the second +2

jyellick
2016-10-20 20:59
Great, thanks, I had seen changesets with two +2's and no merge, so just wanted to make sure it was okay for the second +2 to merge

ghaskins
2016-10-21 02:19
@muralisr here:

ghaskins
2016-10-21 02:19
so, one thought I had is that: I have projects that are built on the current architecture…in fact, something between v0.5 and v0.6 releases

ghaskins
2016-10-21 02:20
i have a few patches in master that make master more interesting to me rather than v0.6 moving forward over the next few months

ghaskins
2016-10-21 02:20
(while 1.0 stablizes

ghaskins
2016-10-21 02:20
it would be nice to somehow preserve the current state of master as a bridge of “newer than v0.6.1” but more mature than convergence/1.0

ghaskins
2016-10-21 02:21
so my question is: does anyone care?

ghaskins
2016-10-21 02:21
if so, one thing we could do is merge the current master to v0.6 and cut v0.6.2 from those changes

ghaskins
2016-10-21 02:21
alternatively, we could make a “v0.7” branch from master

ghaskins
2016-10-21 02:22
or, we say screw it and convergence gets folded into master and we are just looking forward

ghaskins
2016-10-21 02:22
thoughts?

ghaskins
2016-10-21 02:22

ghaskins
2016-10-21 02:23

garisingh
2016-10-21 09:21
@ghaskins - what do you mean by "your needs"? I think that we (maintainers) need to agree on the guidance moving forward. My assertion is quite simple: the `v0.6 branch` should not be planning additional releases other than fixing bugs with the current feature set. `master branch` needs to be dedicated to v1.0 development.

garisingh
2016-10-21 09:22
or forever, no new features in v0.6 :wink:

ghaskins
2016-10-21 11:34
@garisingh: I just mean that outside of my community activity, I have a team building things in hyperledger: we are currently building them on a fairly old tree that sits somewhere between the v0.5 and v0.6 releases. I am interested in picking up some of the latest work, including the baseimage update and shim changes. The v0.6 branch is a little too old, the convergence branch is too new, and the master branch is "just right". So, what I am wondering is if there is anyone else out there either like me, or can sympathize with me, about this dilemma

ghaskins
2016-10-21 11:34
Otherwise, I'll probably have to maintain this on my own (which is fine, just not ideal)

ghaskins
2016-10-21 11:35
It sounds like the inertia is really behind convergence though, and that is fine

ghaskins
2016-10-21 11:35
Who knows, maybe convergence is stable enough that we can use it

jzhang
2016-10-21 11:44
can one of you guys help out a community contributor with this? https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1823/, it’s really trivial (inline doc update), but would encourage this first-time contributor

ghaskins
2016-10-21 11:47
@jzhang: someone said yesterday that we shouldn't be accepting any more SDK patches in master

ghaskins
2016-10-21 11:47

garisingh
2016-10-21 11:48

ghaskins
2016-10-21 11:48

ghaskins
2016-10-21 11:49

ghaskins
2016-10-21 11:51
I have no problem with the patch. If you are ok with more patches going in @jzhang I'll merge this when at my desk

ghaskins
2016-10-21 11:52
Any objections @garisingh

ghaskins
2016-10-21 11:52
?

garisingh
2016-10-21 11:54
I don't have an issue, although I think the patch will end up going no where since the SDK will be removed from master soon I believe. So if someone wants to get it in, it would make sense to put it in the v0.6 branch (which we REALLY don't want to encourage). But I have no problem with it, I just think that he'll never see the fruit of his labor :disappointed:

garisingh
2016-10-21 11:56
Back to the previous discussion on releases, here's the dilemma as I see it: 1) It has really been a struggle for people who just want to use the fabric and develop chaincode and applications up to this point. I've seen that at several hackathons, etc. The reason is that it is VERY hard to figure out what works with what. Things like shim changes between v0.5 and v0.6 plus the fact that Go has no versioning in terms of packages have really been a problem. Also, interface changes make it tough to keep the NodeSDK compatible with release versions of the fabric 2) We are REALLY struggling to get the V1 work to be the focus for the community as well as get an integrated end to end working version of V1 which we can now fully test and add to. In order to do this, we need to strip out all of the code from the prior (through v0.6) architecture which really means that the v0.6 branch needs to become that last release of the old architecture

ghaskins
2016-10-21 12:05
Ok, that's fine as long as it's understood that can go the other way too

ghaskins
2016-10-21 12:06
But I agree that the branches are painful and the antithesis of real "CI"

ghaskins
2016-10-21 12:07
That's why I was advocating perhaps one more v0.6.2 actually

ghaskins
2016-10-21 12:07
Capture the work in master before it's lost in the shuffle

ghaskins

ghaskins

ghaskins

2016-10-23 21:04

ghaskins
2016-10-23 21:05

ry
2016-10-23 21:06
well, it’s the most direct way

ry
2016-10-23 21:16
that is what I just tested and the size of the change looked the same, but I am wary of proclaiming it’s the One Right Way because I know I’m retrograde

ghaskins
2016-10-23 21:17
@muralisr i get lots of merge conflicts during the rebase, I assume that is expected?

muralisr
2016-10-23 21:17
yes

muralisr
2016-10-23 21:19

2016-10-23 21:21

ghaskins

muralisr

ry
2016-10-23 21:25

ry
2016-10-23 21:25
so having the same change-id on two branches is no problem

muralisr
2016-10-23 21:40

2016-10-23 21:45

2016-10-23 21:47

2016-10-23 21:48

2016-10-23 21:48
with the correct paths, of course

2016-10-23 21:49

2016-10-23 21:49

2016-10-23 21:54

ry
2016-10-23 21:54

muralisr
2016-10-24 12:09
Thanks to @ry and @ghaskins suggestions, I was able to bring https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1633/ from convergence into https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1919/ in master with these following instructions

muralisr
2016-10-24 12:09
```git clone git fetch http://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/fabric refs/changes/33/1633/7 && git checkout FETCH_HEAD git checkout master git checkout -b post_merge_organization_1 git cherry-pick 3ecced6 <resolve conflicts ... > git cherry-pick --continue git push origin HEAD:refs/for/master```

muralisr
2016-10-24 12:10
`3ecced6` is the CR of 1633

muralisr
2016-10-24 12:10
there may be other ways to make this work of course...

muralisr
2016-10-24 12:12
Given 1633 went thru review and 1919 passes, could we get some +2’s for 1919 so we can merge it into master please ?

muralisr
2016-10-24 13:52
Also @ry @ghaskins I don;t need the `git fetch` above right ? I was using it for the rebase approach but don’t need it for the cherry-pick approach, true ?

dave.enyeart
2016-10-24 14:09
When using feature/convergence I would navigate to the open reviews by going to Branches—>feature/convergence—>gitweb—>review. This always worked for me. But with master the same navigation does not work. Branches—>master—>gitweb—>review returns an error. You can use the direct URL as a workaround. https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/q/refs/heads/master. @ry any ideas?

garisingh
2016-10-24 14:11
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/q/status:open+project:fabric+branch:master is what I use

ghaskins
2016-10-24 14:27
@muralisr: the git fetch is still needed, but you could have condensed a few operations

ghaskins
2016-10-24 14:28
git fetch && git cherry-pick FETCH_HEAD

ghaskins
2016-10-24 14:28
That could have been used instead of a few of the lines there

ghaskins
2016-10-24 14:29
But same effect

muralisr
2016-10-24 14:54
thanks @ghaskins

muralisr
2016-10-24 15:25
@cbf I think @garisingh suggested we at least start with memberservices immediately. For others, if any, suggest we complete all the cleanup first so we have a good idea of dependencies (starting with https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1633/) ?

ghaskins
2016-10-24 15:25
@ghaskins uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ghaskins/F2TCJQWSD/-.pl and commented: @muralisr minimal and (IMO) more direct instructions

ghaskins
2016-10-24 15:26
for one thing, fewer steps. But most importantly, it takes advantage of the FETCH_HEAD refspec instead of requiring the user to look it up (or leave it open to make a mistake)

garisingh
2016-10-24 15:27
@cbf - I think that @keithsmith and the "COP" team would be ready for a new "fabric-cop" repo :wink:

muralisr
2016-10-24 15:28
@ghaskins ` But most importantly, it takes advantage of the FETCH_HEAD refspec instead of requiring the user to look it up` how does the above instructions do that ? missing that..

ghaskins
2016-10-24 15:29
compare to your original step 6

ghaskins
2016-10-24 15:29
you did a checkout to FETCH_HEAD, then overwrote that with a checkout of master, then (after creating a working branch), cherry-picked the explicit git sha

muralisr
2016-10-24 15:29
right.. I didn’t read the checkout->cherrypick

muralisr
2016-10-24 15:30
that works

ghaskins
2016-10-24 15:30
im just saying that you dont need all that…after the fetch, FETCH_HEAD == 3ecced67d

ghaskins
2016-10-24 15:30
(git assigns a few tags dynamically, like ORIG_HEAD, FETCH_HEAD, HEAD, etc

ghaskins
2016-10-24 15:31
so, for instance, you can do “git merge .. && git show ORIG_HEAD” and you would see what your HEAD was _before_ you did the git-merge

ghaskins
2016-10-24 15:31
which is helpful if you decide that was a bad idea to do the merge :wink:

ghaskins
2016-10-24 15:31
e.g. git reset —hard ORIG_HEAD

ghaskins
2016-10-24 15:31
in this case, FETCH_HEAD is one of those helpers

muralisr
2016-10-24 15:31
I need that REAL bad :wink:

ghaskins
2016-10-24 15:32
it gets set to the last fetch you did

ghaskins
2016-10-24 15:32
just note: “git reset —hard” is a big freakin hammer

ghaskins
2016-10-24 15:32
treat with the same respect as “rm -rf"

ghaskins
2016-10-24 15:32
if you had local edits not saved elsewhere, buh-bye

muralisr
2016-10-24 15:33
right. understood…also extremely convenient :wink:

ghaskins
2016-10-24 15:33
have to step away for a few, bbiab

jzhang
2016-10-25 20:20

jzhang
2016-10-25 20:21
