garisingh
2016-10-25 20:37
I commented on this - somehow I never posted my comment before

garisingh
2016-10-25 20:37
I don't support this approach of tagging images from within peer code

garisingh
2016-10-25 20:39
you either pull the image and retag before running the fabric or we can use our compose trick to do it. but doing this tagging from within the peer is not a good idea IMHO. But hey - we have other maintainers :wink:

hgabor
2016-10-26 08:14
@garisingh yes it is magic. @ghaskins and me thought that this is only temporary

hgabor
2016-10-26 08:15
if you tell me where to detail the process of tagging (e.g. one has to download the image and tag it etc etc) and we agree in a proper process I can do that

garisingh
2016-10-26 10:53
@hgabor - btw - realize my statement might have been a little harsh :wink: I just think that hard-coding things in code will get us into trouble. Not sure where we should detail the process - maybe we need to do it here: http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Setup/Network-setup/#pulling-the-images-from-dockerhub (although this is for v0.6 at this point). So perhaps we need to find a spot in the new SDK docs to add it?

garisingh
2016-10-26 10:55
although for v0.6 we should also add the ``` docker pull hyperledger:fabric-baseimage:$ARCH docker tag hyperledger:fabric-baseimage:$ARCH hyperledger/fabric-baseimage:latest ``` or `docker tag hyperledger/fabric-peer hyperledger/fabric-baseimage:latest`

garisingh
2016-10-26 10:55
(I use the second one myself)

garisingh
2016-10-26 10:57
if anyone's out there, this one is now ready: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1987/ (remove the sdk from fabric master)

garisingh
2016-10-26 11:12
any reason not to merge this: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2015/ ?

muralisr
2016-10-26 11:33
@garisingh just answered to a question from @hgabor. I think its ready for merge

garisingh
2016-10-26 11:37
merged

muralisr
2016-10-26 11:56
thank s @garisingh

hgabor
2016-10-26 12:06
@garisingh > although for v0.6 we should also add the

hgabor
2016-10-26 12:06
if we use the image:$ARCH tag then that will lead to automatic image download, or not?

garisingh
2016-10-26 12:21
it will lead to download but of course right now the SDK uses the `:latest` tag when building the chaincode container. So at some point in the "setup" process we'll need to tell people to download the image and re-tag it. In the IBM images we just released (which are basically the HL images), we use a little trick in our compose file to "create" the base image on the fly - https://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/fabric-images/tree/master/docker-compose

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:24
@garisingh: why would we _not_ want to do this? The software cannot function without the proper ccenv and the peer has enough information to automate the setup. Why leave it as a manual step?

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:26
Ultimately the SDK needs to get away from specifying a Dockerfile, but that will take some more work...until then the image is required and I see no reason to leave it a manual step

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:27
All we really want to achieve is to have parity between build-from-source and binary-deployment

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:28
The build synthesizes the :latest tag, we want to move that to runtime so both modes are supported

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:29
I'd like users to be able to stand up a peer with nothing more than "docker run ...peer"

garisingh
2016-10-26 12:29
as I said, people can override me. History tells me that hardcoding things in code never leads to anything good. We already tell people that they need to download or pull the peer and fabric images so why not just tell them to pull and tag the CC images as well?

garisingh
2016-10-26 12:30
then we should fix the SDK and not hardcode something in the peer

garisingh
2016-10-26 12:31
we can do the same thing in a compose file then

garisingh
2016-10-26 12:31
and tell people to use compose to run the peer

garisingh
2016-10-26 12:31
all I am saying is that hardcoded strings are a bad idea IMHO :wink:

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:31
I fully agree that hardcoding is bad, but note that the hard coding of a FROM target in the SDK is the fundamental problem. We are just trying to put a temporary solution in place to actually accommodate that decision.

garisingh
2016-10-26 12:31
but we COULD fix that easily

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:32
With what?

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:32
I'm open to that

garisingh
2016-10-26 12:33
hmm - maybe not so easily if we assume heterogeneous hosts for peers in a network. So I take that back

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:33
Exactly

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:33
That was our conclusion as well

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:33
This patch lets the peer do the right thing

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:33
In a heterogeneous environment

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:34
"latest" then is contextually correct regardless of the composition

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:36
Moving forward, the vision/proposal is that the chaincode/SDK only declare requirements, and the peer can decide how to fulfill them

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:37
Kind of like "Java 1.8" vs 1.7

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:38
This is a baby step to address limitations to the current architecture

garisingh
2016-10-26 12:39
but hang-on - maybe I am reading the code wrong - but it still seems that you need to actually download / pull the CC image in any case

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:39
No, i think it will get pulled by the tag. We should confirm that though

garisingh
2016-10-26 12:39
unless ``` ccenv := util.ParseDockerfileTemplate("hyperledger/fabric-ccenv:$(ARCH)-$(PROJECT_VERSION)") tagoptions := docker.TagImageOptions{Repo: "hyperledger/fabric-ccenv", Tag: "latest"} tagerr := d.TagImage(ccenv, tagoptions) ``` does more than I think

garisingh
2016-10-26 12:40
maybe it actually does pull it?

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:40
I'll try to confirm this pulls it too, that was the intent

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:40
I think so, and I agree that is a requirement

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:40
Otherwise has limited utility

garisingh
2016-10-26 12:42
via `docker` CLI does not appear to work

hgabor
2016-10-26 12:43
yeah I am not sure 'tag' will pull

garisingh
2016-10-26 12:43
`docker tag hyperledger/fabric-ccenv:x86_64-0.6.1-preview gari:gari` this failed until after I ran `docker pull docker tag hyperledger/fabric-ccenv:x86_64-0.6.1-preview`

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:44
Good catch

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:44
@hgabor: I assume that is a trivial mod to drive via the API

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:44
?

garisingh
2016-10-26 12:45
https://godoc.org/github.com/fsouza/go-dockerclient#Client.PullImage

garisingh
2016-10-26 12:46
personally I would still prefer to do it outside of the peer process but as I said I am just one dissenter :wink:

garisingh
2016-10-26 12:46
@cbf - what are your thoughts here ^^^^

hgabor
2016-10-26 12:47
@ghaskins I hope yes

hgabor
2016-10-26 12:52
@garisingh should we go with this solution or prefer the manual tagging?

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:58
I still think we should automate it. I get a constant stream of bugs/questions about this when a newbie joins the project

garisingh
2016-10-26 12:58
I vote for manual tagging but as I said that's just me. I think telling people to do: ``` docker pull hyperledger:fabric-peer:$ARCH-$RELEASE docker pull hyperledger:fabric-membersrvc:$ARCH-$RELEASE docker pull hyperledger:fabric-ccenv:$ARCH-$RELEASE docker tag hyperledger:fabric-ccenv:$ARCH-$RELEASE hyperledger:fabric-ccenv:latest ``` is no more complex than ``` docker pull hyperledger:fabric-peer:$ARCH-$RELEASE docker pull hyperledger:fabric-membersrvc:$ARCH-$RELEASE ``` which they will have to do anyway for each platform

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:59
And the peer has all the info/access

ghaskins
2016-10-26 12:59
I see your point though

garisingh
2016-10-26 12:59
and we can do what we did here - https://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/fabric-images/tree/master/docker-compose to make it easier for users on a single platform

garisingh
2016-10-26 13:01
I've made my case and beat this to death so up to the rest of you :wink:

ghaskins
2016-10-26 13:02
Yes, I see your point. We could address with doc until we have something that fixes it for real

garisingh
2016-10-26 13:02
like Docker supporting ARCH :wink: ?

hgabor
2016-10-26 13:02
I think it is better to automate things but it is really weird that peer calls docker and tag and etc.

ghaskins
2016-10-26 13:03
With a simple tag, I was happy as I thought it would handle pull vs locally available already. But since it apparently doesn't, that could complicate things

hgabor
2016-10-26 13:03
btw I still on the automation side :smile: as a temporary solution

ghaskins
2016-10-26 13:03
For instance, will the pull API call return failure if the image is local but not on dockerhub?

hgabor
2016-10-26 13:03
no

ghaskins
2016-10-26 13:04
That could be a problem

hgabor
2016-10-26 13:04
I don't think

ghaskins
2016-10-26 13:04
Ok

hgabor
2016-10-26 13:05
if you pull docker pull fabric/ccenv:latest then it will find it locally or pull from docker hub, it doesn't care which happens. no?

garisingh
2016-10-26 13:05
it should just return that it already has the latest if you have it locally and the hash matches

ghaskins
2016-10-26 13:08
I seem to recall having to deal with the difference in the old docker.sh script

ghaskins
2016-10-26 13:08
I might be mistaken, and the cmdline might act differently than the API

garisingh
2016-10-26 13:08

hgabor
2016-10-26 13:09

garisingh

2016-10-26 13:23

2016-10-27 09:18

hgabor

ghaskins
2016-10-27 14:42
@cbf: i see there are new submissions against v0.6 (https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/q/status:open+branch:v0.6)

ghaskins
2016-10-27 14:42
should we be considering these for a potential v0.6.2 release, or is the branch closed?

garisingh
2016-10-27 15:33
my hope was that we would only accept 2 types of PRs for v0.6 branch: 1) fix bugs found by people trying to use the Docker images in the wild 2) if we wanted to merge in any build changes to add support for Power and/or Z for both build and CI

garisingh
2016-10-27 15:34
I'd like fabric users to focus on building chaincode and apps with v0.6 and fabric developers to help with v1.0 work. Of course advanced users should be using v1.0 builds once we have the basics going

weeds
2016-10-27 16:23
@ghaskins I feel like we really should shift people to the v1.0 work- this is what community decided on in general at the hackathons and through all the specification work (like SDK workgroup), right? I can see basic bug fixes as Gari Singh has commented on, but major features seems like should be focused on what community decided upon.

ghaskins
2016-10-27 17:03
i dont have a super strong opinion either way, but I was under the impression that the branch was closed for the reasons you mentioned (community focus, etc) but then was surprised when more CRs came in

ghaskins
2016-10-27 17:03
so the question now is: what to do about them? review/accept, or redirect to master?

weeds
2016-10-27 17:05
as long as not major bug- i say redirect to master

dave.enyeart

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:01
@cbf https://github.com/ghaskins/hyperledger-fabric/tree/docker-native

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:01
I just had a UT failure, still need to diagnose that

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:01
but at least you have a preview

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:02
also note, there is an incompatibility between bsdtar and gnutar that will preclude the build from working on a pure native OSX setup

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:02
I fixed my system by doing: 'brew install --with-default-names gnu-tar'

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:03
but will need to think about that some more

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:03
I also was testing against the old docker-machine, not the new docker-for-mac

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:03
will check that next

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:04
long story short: I got rid of all(most) of the native binaries...now "make peer" will emit hyperledger/fabric-peer docker image, for instance

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:04
and "make unit-test" runs all the tests inside docker

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:04
etc

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:05
also, I cleaned up the docker files to make the UX a littler smoother...for instance, peer implicitly runs 'CMD peer node start'

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:06
this means we can just do "docker run hyperledger/fabric-peer"

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:06
check it out and let me know what you think

cbf

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:14
pull that branch, then simply “make peer” or “make unit-test” from whatever environment you are in

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:14
i do assume a few basics, like git, make, docker

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:14
but it no longer requires the devenv

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:15
you can detect if you have that bsdtar problem if you see the message: Error processing tar file(bzip2 data invalid: bad magic value in continuation file):

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:15
as mentioned before, you can fix this with: brew install --with-default-names gnu-tar

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:15
but note that updates the $PATH with gnu-tar, not sure that is what you want

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:17
one other tip: be sure to set your GOPATH to include the fabric as $GOPATH/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric, or things wont build right

ghaskins
2016-11-01 20:19
seems to be working fine with docker-for-mac too

@c0rwin - there is an error in the logrus package in the vendor folder when compiling on Mac. Find the package and look for `terminal_bsd.go` and delete `darwin` from the top line

cbf
2016-11-02 12:47
I envisioned a model where the codebase is mounted into a base image container and the build and tests execute IN the container. This seems (correct me if I am mistaken) to be a native build, which is also goodness, however, it means that when a changeset is submitted, it might pass on native mac or windows but fail for ubuntu, etc

ghaskins
2016-11-02 12:48
i think if you dig in deeper, you'll see thats exactly what we are doing

ghaskins
2016-11-02 12:48
not much is actually run "native" aside from commands like git/make/docker/tar

ghaskins
2016-11-02 12:48
everything else is happening in a docker environment

ghaskins
2016-11-02 12:48
(such as go-build, etc)

ghaskins
2016-11-02 12:49
I do currently rely on things like "go list" and "git ls-files" to run native

ghaskins
2016-11-02 12:49
though that could change if necessary

ghaskins
2016-11-02 12:49
but as an example:

ghaskins
2016-11-02 12:50
https://github.com/ghaskins/hyperledger-fabric/blob/docker-native/scripts/goUnitTests.sh#L42

ghaskins
2016-11-02 12:50
in this example, you can see the UTs now run inside a docker-run context

ghaskins
2016-11-02 12:51
this comes from this change

ghaskins
2016-11-02 12:51
https://github.com/ghaskins/hyperledger-fabric/commit/5e18563bd5e16a6fb8100d2f0210524d9362b085

ghaskins
2016-11-02 12:52
it might be easier to review if you look patch by patch: https://github.com/ghaskins/hyperledger-fabric/commits/docker-native

ghaskins
2016-11-02 12:53
This is another major one where I moved the linter to run inside docker: https://github.com/ghaskins/hyperledger-fabric/commit/1ff77ff910d04b257db56b1774fd534e9092b010

ghaskins
2016-11-02 12:57
@hgabor @garisingh regarding CR 1649: I was thinking more about @garisingh said about just requiring the user to manually tag things, and I am not sure that will work well in all scenarios

ghaskins
2016-11-02 12:58
for instance, deploying to kubernetes, I dont easily have access to the docker catalog

cbf
2016-11-02 12:58
@jzhang merged… I want to point out though that code coverage has dipped below 50%. This is unacceptable

ghaskins
2016-11-02 12:58
so, it would be nice to have something like CR 1649 in place so I can deploy "fabric-peer" and have it take care of the rest (kind of like how kubernetes itself works)

cbf
2016-11-02 12:58
I want developers doing test driven development

cbf
2016-11-02 12:58
I want developers writing the unit tests before the code

cbf
2016-11-02 12:59
testing is not and cannot be an afterthought

cbf
2016-11-02 12:59
it is fundamental

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:02
@cbf in light of above ^^^, do you think it might be closer to what you envisioned after all? Or did I still miss the mark?

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:04
in summary, the meat of everything (except behave, i havent ported that yet) is now done inside a normalized docker environment, though I do rely on a few native tools like make/git/go/docker to orchestrate it all

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:04
my thought was, those tools are ubiquitous...whereas things like librocksdb have been a PITA

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:04
(and I only rely on "go" at a high level, like for accumulating package lists, etc

hgabor
2016-11-02 13:08
@ghaskins you mean user tagging won't go easily? For me, the best temporary solution seems to be still tagging from peer

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:09
@hgabor to be clear: I am trying to say that I think CR 1649 is more appropriate solution than relying on explicit user action

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:09
and therefore, my vote is to merge

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:09
without it, my kubernetes deployments are not going to work properly

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:10
i am still trying to rapidly converge on the point where even 1649 isnt necessary, but we are not there yet

cbf
2016-11-02 13:11
@ghaskins digging

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:14
@cbf also note I exploit an overarching pattern here: Quite a few things run in two phases

cbf
2016-11-02 13:15
ah, I see what you did there

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:15
a docker-run phase, which does the compilation, saving results to a volume-mount, and a second phase issuing a docker-build to seal the artifacts in

cbf
2016-11-02 13:15
ok, so for the unit tests, we need to exploit @garisingh docker in docker approach

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:16
(this will pave the way to having lighter weight final artifacts, like alpine images with just "peer" binary

cbf
2016-11-02 13:16
eg rather than docker run, use compose and stand up a dind container along side of the peer container

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:16
you mean for the unit-test execution?

cbf
2016-11-02 13:16
yes

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:16
does docker-compose handle dind for you?

cbf
2016-11-02 13:17
and behave

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:18
and can you clarify: there are two types of "dind"...there is the literal "dind" project which nests the containers, and there is the "-H" method which just points the tooling to a remote dockerd

cbf
2016-11-02 13:19
https://github.com/mastersingh24/fabric05-docker/blob/master/fabric05/compose/single-peer-ca.yaml

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:19
we have, for a long time, used the -H method...and from what I have read, it might be the generally easier/better solution to work with over true dind

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:19
(because of the security implications and asymmetric behavior it tends to have

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:19
what are your thoughts there?

cbf
2016-11-02 13:19
he had to do some tweaks but basically, the first is a derivative of docker in docker

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:20
ok, ill take a look at that

cbf
2016-11-02 13:20
https://github.com/docker-library/docker/blob/36e2107fb879d5d5c3dbb5d8d93aeef0a2d45ac8/1.12/Dockerfile

cbf
2016-11-02 13:20
note that is based on alpine

cbf
2016-11-02 13:21
I think that we’d need an ubuntu version of dind

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:21
so is @garisingh using a dind based image as the base? or is he just using privledged mode with -H?

cbf
2016-11-02 13:22
I need to dig a bit to find where he builds this image

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:22
i still need to confirm this, but I think the -H pseudo dind would work if I simply ran the UTs with --privledged

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:22
on a related note: the peer needs to be able to create docker containers too, technically...how does this work today?

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:22
are we just getting lucky that the UTs do not deploy anything?

hgabor
2016-11-02 13:24
@ghaskins I see, and what do the others think of CR 1649?

cbf
2016-11-02 13:27
this is where the dind comes in

cbf
2016-11-02 13:28
basically, we tell the peer that the docker daemon address is named ‘docker’ and set the CORE_VM_ENDPOINT accordingly - CORE_VM_ENDPOINT=http://docker:2375

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:28
to keep them straight, lets differentiate them as dind-true and dind-H

cbf
2016-11-02 13:28
so when the peer spins up a chaincode container, it just asks the daemon in the dind container

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:28
right, so I would classify CORE_VM_ENDPOINT as "dind-H"

cbf
2016-11-02 13:28
yes

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:29
dind-true is different in that the dockerd runs inside the docker container, and actually nests the underlying containers under itself

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:29
whereas dind-H simply fires up containers at the same level as itself

cbf
2016-11-02 13:29
oh, misunderstood

cbf
2016-11-02 13:29
then no

cbf
2016-11-02 13:29
you want true I believe where the containers run inside the dind container

cbf
2016-11-02 13:29
russian dolls

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:30
ideally, yes....there are a few issues we need to work through though

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:30
(and we dont use dind-true today, afaick)

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:31
i think architecturally, dind-true makes the most sense

cbf
2016-11-02 13:31
we don’t now, no

cbf
2016-11-02 13:31
this is a new approach

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:31
but from a practical perspective, its not super mature yet

cbf
2016-11-02 13:31
keeps things tidier

cbf
2016-11-02 13:31
this is true

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:31
right...will become more important to manage the namespace

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:32
anyway, where I am going with this is: I think I can get dind-H in place trivially

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:32
dind-true might take a bit more work/vetting

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:32
if thats the case, I think the UTs would be unblocked in the new model

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:33
i do hope, for a later phase, to move to alpine for the baseimage anyway, which might make things easier to incorporate dind-true at that time

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:34
does that sound like an acceptable plan?

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:36
i think we are no worse for the wear....we essentially let the UTs drive dockerd on the host today by running them natively...if we then push the UTs into a dind-H container, they are still just driving containers on the host all the same

ghaskins
2016-11-02 13:36
this is more of an important concept for the peer itself IMO...would be nice to namespace scope the chaincode containers under the peer

garisingh
2016-11-02 13:44
sure - we can just mount the host docker daemon to a UT container

garisingh
2016-11-02 13:45
if we name the UT container, then docker networking should let any child containers communicate back to any endpoint on the UT container

cbf
2016-11-02 13:47
I think that using Alpine is a good idea, but I also think that some market analysis needs to be done as to how acceptable that might be

garisingh
2016-11-02 13:48
we should at least pair down to debian:jessie :wink:

garisingh
2016-11-02 13:48
(I was going to see if we can get Alpine approved by IBM) :wink:

cbf
2016-11-02 14:09
I was more thinking about enterprise use/acceptance

cbf
2016-11-02 14:11
eg who does triage and mitigation for CVEs?

cbf
2016-11-02 14:11
HPE seemed to be on this but has not been updated for 5 months

cbf
2016-11-02 14:11
https://github.com/eedevops/alpine-cve-db

ghaskins
2016-11-02 14:19
@cbf i hadnt thought of it from that angle

ghaskins
2016-11-02 14:20
long story short, with the current ubuntu design, I think I can eventually get fabric-peer image to about 150M (uncompressed)

cbf
2016-11-02 14:20
Alpine is community driven… this is a good thing, but enterprises want assurances

ghaskins
2016-11-02 14:20
and I think that would drop to closer to 15-20M on alpine

ghaskins
2016-11-02 14:20
so, its a big drop, but 150M isnt bad either

cbf
2016-11-02 14:20
150 better than 1.6G

ghaskins
2016-11-02 14:20
right

cbf
2016-11-02 14:21
you are removing the build time dependencies from the base image?

ghaskins
2016-11-02 14:21
I am still less alarmed about the 1.6G than others...its 400M download and you only pay it once

ghaskins
2016-11-02 14:21
but still, i understand the concern and I think we can fix it

ghaskins
2016-11-02 14:21
well, not in this series/effort, but that is my thinking yes

ghaskins
2016-11-02 14:23
im thinking "baseimage" gets split into, say baseimage (with just minimum runtime, librocksdb.so, etc), "builder" (kind of what baseimage is today, with full golang, protoc, etc), and possibly "testenv"

ghaskins
2016-11-02 14:23
they would have a derivative relationship: baseimage -> builder -> testenv

ghaskins
2016-11-02 14:23
(where testenv has all the extra crap for testing, like behave/docker-compose, etc

ghaskins
2016-11-02 14:24
anyway, to the point of the multi-phase build: I would run the build-phase with the builder image, produce artifacts to the volume mount, and then seal them in the minimal baseimage

ghaskins
2016-11-02 14:25
im actually _almost_ there now if I just use xenial instead of a stripped down form form of baseimage, except its missing librocksdb.so

ghaskins
2016-11-02 14:25
as a POC

cbf
2016-11-02 19:03
@garisingh @ghaskins and any others… was chatting with @jzhang about testing for SDK which requires images

cbf
2016-11-02 19:04
hence to develop for node, java etc SDK you need to build your own images

cbf
2016-11-02 19:04
this is probably unnecessary

garisingh
2016-11-02 19:04
we should be able to avoid that

cbf
2016-11-02 19:05
I wonder what others think about pushing images out of the build and labeling them “unstable” or something

cbf
2016-11-02 19:05
these could be used for development and testing and the more adventurous

cbf
2016-11-02 19:05
thoughts?

ghaskins
2016-11-02 19:06
im not for or against the idea, but I will note that the "-snapshot" that we currently label them with is sufficient in regards to the "unstable" nature, IMO

ghaskins
2016-11-02 19:07
theres plenty of precedent for that, at least

jonathanlevi
2016-11-02 19:08
I don’t think this is a bad idea. Generated (only) by the CI - with a ‘naming scheme’ which allows us to pull the exact built image and test locally… will allow everyone to reuse it. “-snapshot” is fine. We’ll have the version/hash as part of the build, etc. Sounds good to me.

ghaskins
2016-11-02 19:09
i would like to understand more about the use case before making any further recommendations

ghaskins
2016-11-02 19:10
for instance, the fact that we label -snapshot-$sha means we will be adding a lot more artifacts to dockerhub than we would in the more traditional undecorated "-snapshot" label scenario

ghaskins
2016-11-02 19:11
so, id like to understand how these artifacts are expected to be consumed....I may prefer to drop the -sha depending on the answert

ghaskins
2016-11-02 19:12
for example: does SDK want a stable coordinate, a stable release, a coupled version, or just "whatever"

jzhang
2016-11-02 19:24
@ghaskins i think there are two primary use cases from the SDK’s point of view: 1) CI job 2) contributor’s local testing

jzhang
2016-11-02 19:24
for #1 we’ll want to run against the latest fabric images

jzhang
2016-11-02 19:25
for #2 a developer may choose the latest or a more “stable” version depending on what they are coding up

jzhang
2016-11-02 19:26
“stable” in relative terms, like “from last sprint” but not much older than that given the fast pace in fabric progression

jzhang

2016-11-04 19:16

garisingh
2016-11-04 19:19
we need some careful thought here about how best to do this given we are updating the fabric pretty regularly (hopefully the protos stabilize very soon) and of course we have multiple SDKs in play now. I think we need to start pushing regular Docker dev images for the fabric master repo. Those should be used by the various SDK CI jobs

garisingh
2016-11-04 19:19
ideally we can also have it so that pushing a new fabric build automatically triggers the CIs for the SDKs so we can quickly find interop failures

garisingh
2016-11-04 19:20

cbf
2016-11-04 19:22

cbf
2016-11-04 19:22

jzhang
2016-11-04 19:23

cbf
2016-11-04 19:24
so, I’d like to talk about docs

cbf
2016-11-04 19:24
currently, the “latest” docs are out of synch

cbf
2016-11-04 19:25
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2127/

cbf
2016-11-04 19:25
@muralisr made the comment that rather than update the docs he would just add a comment in the commit on how to use the revised chaincode api

cbf
2016-11-04 19:26
this is a problem IMO

cbf
2016-11-04 19:26
we should be requiring documentation changes with API changes in the same commit

cbf
2016-11-04 19:26
we can clean up the grammar and so forth after the fact, but if we want to have people using the code, then we need to have docs that they can trust

cbf
2016-11-04 19:27
also too, the unit test coverage is slipping and that needs to be addressed

cbf
2016-11-04 19:28
I think that there is talk of cutting a release in the next week or so that captures the skeleton end-2-end operations

cbf
2016-11-04 19:28
if that is the case, then the tests and the docs need to be up to date

cbf
2016-11-04 19:29
they don’t need to be pretty, but the devs that made the changes are the ones that need to review the docs and change as required

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:31
@garisingh what you describe above is probably better suited to a jenkins pipeline than dockerhub

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:32
e.g. merge kicks off build, build produces artifact, artifact triggers [fabric-unit-tests, sdk-unit-tests], etc

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:33
we dont necessarily need that artifact to be pushed to a public namespace, and there is a good reason not to

garisingh
2016-11-04 19:37
@ghaskins - cool. that's why I tagged you - keep me in line :wink:

garisingh
2016-11-04 19:37
sounds like what I was looking for

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:39
When do we want to release a ‘cut’ ?

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:39
Off `master` that is?

cbf
2016-11-04 19:39
I could see pushing to an alternate namespace for the unstable builds

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:39
[Thanks for the heads-up. It’s good to know/plan for it]

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:40
@cbf the general problem I have with the “non pipeline, push to a namespace” model is often too decoupled…it lacks precision

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:40
for instance, if we push everything to “-nightly”, its not precise, its not repeatable

cbf
2016-11-04 19:41
what you described - merge triggers build/publish makes sense to me - isn’t that what we do for a release?

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:41
the decoupling to the repo is the problem, i think

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:41
yes, but a release is different because its generally a precise coordinate

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:41
v0.6.1-preview is precise

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:42
-snapshot is not

garisingh
2016-11-04 19:42
snapshot-<change_id> would be :wink:

cbf
2016-11-04 19:43
no but it is no different than a local build… I think that the point is to make images available for testing and for advanced development

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:43
so you end up with this problem where you either need to create precise coordinates and communicate them to the consumers, or not use precise coordinates and risk non deterministic behavor

cbf
2016-11-04 19:43
I can see then use of another namespace with clarity that this is UNSTABLE

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:43
Greg: what’s the problem with `precise coordinates`? (the frequency?)

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:43
all I am really saying is there are flows we can exploit that are precise and solve the communication problem that dont involve a tagged artifact in the namespace

cbf
2016-11-04 19:44
well, I suppose we could host our own registry

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:44
@jonathanlevi ultimately we need precision, the problem is how to communicate that to the consumer

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:45
all I am saying is that a pipeline model was kind of designed exactly for this

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:45
one jobs output is the input to one or more other jobs

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:45
its both precise and communicated

cbf
2016-11-04 19:45
I suppose we could do a daily build

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:45
Yes, that’s why I am asking. We need the precise/deterministic/reproducible/...

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:45
@cbf, @ghaskins Yes, with a date.

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:46
(or a date+ checkin!)

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:46
in the true CI sense, it should be every merge

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:46
in the ideal, every commit goes through the pipeline, builds, checks, and possibly, deployment

cbf
2016-11-04 19:46
this is what I was suggesting, but maybe i am misreading you — I thought you were opposed to that?

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:46
With post-build deploy.

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:47
(Writing at the same time). Yes.

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:47
no no, not opposed to that at all…just unsure that pushing each build to dockerhub makes sense

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:47
I am fully in favor of each merge going through a pipeline

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:47
Pushing each build to our own repo (/published directory/registry). Maybe pushing daily to dockethub or even weekly.

cbf
2016-11-04 19:47
ok, so we have the pipeline… the question is how and how frequently we publish images

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:47
Yup

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:48
I’ve been reading a good book on this subject, let me find it

cbf
2016-11-04 19:48
(he doesn’t sleep, I am convinced)

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:49
(not even on a Friday afternoon. 0-siestas-policy !)

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:51
"Continuous Delivery: Reliable Software Releases through Build, Test, and Deployment Automation (Adobe Reader) (Addison-Wesley Signature Series (Fowler))" by Jez Humble, David Farley http://amzn.to/2fkrWfd

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:52
anyway, one of the things I found interesting was the notion that you stay away from the notion of deciding a “release"

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:52
basically, any commit is a potential release

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:52
if it can get through your testing framework, it goes out

garisingh
2016-11-04 19:52
well that's the way it is supposed to be

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:52
not sure we are ready for that though :wink:

garisingh
2016-11-04 19:52
far from it actually

garisingh
2016-11-04 19:52
code wise

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:52
heh

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:53
right…but we should strive for it I think

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:53
anyway, long story short, I am not against a fine grained pipeline

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:53
all I am saying is, a loosely coupled one might be fragile

garisingh
2016-11-04 19:53
yep. but of course you have the naysayers who will say that this just leads to people wasting time fixing CI builds :wink:

garisingh
2016-11-04 19:54
to which I respond - well if you wrote well-tested code this would not be an issue :wink:

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:54
so if the pipeline was such that the SDK just builds whenever the “-unstable” tag moves, thats not a tight integration

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:54
`well if you wrote well-tested code this would not be an issue :` AMEN !

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:54
id rather see it so it walks 1:1 with the artifacts, thus precision

cbf
2016-11-04 19:54
so, yes, I agree on that point about about deciding post facto which build is the release

cbf
2016-11-04 19:55
I would like us to get there

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:55
Alright, so putting my good ol’ banker hat for a second.

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:55
ultimately I think we are all in agreement, its just a matter of semantics

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:55
Where a release to ‘production’ is a big thing.

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:56
They usually have a candidate that goes through an extreme set of tests.

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:56
the “pipeline” could use dockerhub as an intermediate stage

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:56
but all I am saying is, its not strictly necessary

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:56
So it is flagged as “ready for deployment” way down the line...

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:56
jenkins pipeline and/or nexus could serve us well there

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:57
They usually don’t decide in advance what would be a release until after it is built, tested, and in many cases goes through a “staging” environment.

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:57
So bottom line, I agree with not declaring in advance what’s a release.

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:57
@jonathanlevi yes, the stuff ive been reading is basically that, except pushing to “production” is a regular thing (multiple times a day) rather than a red-flag event

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:57
but it has to pass through that gauntlet

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:57
It has to!

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:57
our gauntlet is way too weak right now

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:58
Yup, and we don’t have a staging environment (where you run “the full risk” against that candidate for example)

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:58
whats also interesting here though is the general notion of “build promotion” can have multiple stages

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:58
right!

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:58
Not enough test coverage, yada yada yada.

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:58
so, there could be [dev, qa, prod]

ghaskins
2016-11-04 19:59
any developer can stand up a dev stage on their laptop, but qa|prod stages are the output of the CI/CD system

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 19:59
We had `dev`, `qa` (=test), `staging`, `prod`

ghaskins
2016-11-04 20:00
anyway, we are getting ahead of ourselves…all I was concerned about here is just the proliferation of loosely coupled artifacts to dockerhub

jonathanlevi
2016-11-04 20:00
You can load a system in 2 commands in your terminal, just stating against what binaries you want to execute.

ghaskins
2016-11-04 20:01
and to be clear, I am not saying “-2” to even that, I am just saying, I think we can do better

garisingh
2016-11-04 20:01
on the release thing, it's not only a function of the build working, etc, we need to get into a cadence where we target requirements from JIRA - meaning a release should be made up of a meaningful set of requirements

garisingh
2016-11-04 20:02
that way we can actually ensure that we have an idea of what the heck the thing we put out is actually supposed to accomplish :wink:

ghaskins
2016-11-04 20:02
yeah, I think the CD thing is a better model for, say, an enterprise deployment of a service than it is for “shrink wrapped software"

ghaskins
2016-11-04 20:03
which fabric is closer to the latter

ghaskins
2016-11-04 20:03
but that said, the tight coupling of a build artifact to a test pipeline is a good one, I think

ghaskins
2016-11-04 20:04
even if the goal isnt for CD-style release

garisingh
2016-11-04 20:04
yep. not saying we can't put stuff out incrementally, but when it comes to a major release with big ticket items, you want to have a meaningful set of well tested and documented features which make sense to put out

garisingh
2016-11-04 20:05
It comes down to writing down meaningful requirements, wiring well tested code and having an automated build and test pipeline

garisingh
2016-11-04 20:05
then anything is possible :wink:

ghaskins
2016-11-04 20:05
agreed

ghaskins
2016-11-04 20:06
and in case anyone is not familiar, I was basically thinking something along the lines of; https://github.com/jenkinsci/pipeline-plugin/blob/master/TUTORIAL.md

ghaskins
2016-11-04 20:06
either raw jenkins-pipeline, or possibly a nexus or private docker-repo (though I think nexus offers this) as an intermediate artifact stage

garisingh
2016-11-04 20:08
you always seem to have a plan

garisingh
2016-11-05 09:54
this looks good - https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2077/2 - @ghaskins @cbf

garisingh
2016-11-05 12:02
looks like we are getting caught up in terms of number of open requests

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:25

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:26
I put it out now as a WIP/review

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:26
though the first N patches are not really controversial IMO

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:27
if this direction were to be accepted, what I would expect is that the devenv and cienv will greatly simplify to just be a basic (but recent) docker environment

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:28
(for instance, docker-compose v1.5.2 is what we currently install in the devenv, but its too old to support the --abort-on-container-exit flag that I use to manage the UT lifecycle

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:29
so, minimally, the devenv needs to be upgraded to something newer than v1.5.2...and possibly the cienv too, depending on what its currently using

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-11-08 14:23
cool

ghaskins
2016-11-08 14:24
the thing I dont understand @garisingh is that in master: we map 7051 to localhost:7051

ghaskins
2016-11-08 14:24
so I would think it will work

ghaskins
2016-11-08 14:24
0.0.0.0:7051 wont though

ghaskins
2016-11-08 14:25
the change in 2315 is that I no longer map localhost:7051 because the peer is run as part of a compose, but I set the IP using composition links

garisingh
2016-11-08 14:25
the problem with the chaincode tests which launch chaincode in Docker is that on Mac Docker runs in a VM so it can't talk back to the peer running native on the host unless you use the explicit host address

ghaskins
2016-11-08 14:25
ah, i gotcha

ghaskins
2016-11-08 14:25
we map it, but its not valid there

ghaskins
2016-11-08 14:26
like I said, the intent of this series is to fix OSX support, so you might be jumping the gun trying it prior to the full set

ghaskins
2016-11-08 14:26
(well, not just OSX, but you know what I mean)

garisingh
2016-11-08 14:26
yep

ghaskins
2016-11-08 14:27
I tried to break things out into logical, small, digestable chunks..but the downside is that it might give someone false hope that some capability is useable before it is :wink:

ghaskins
2016-11-08 14:27
in this case, the hope was that I didnt break what currently works while laying the substrate for the real fix

garisingh
2016-11-08 14:28
yeah - just trying to figure out how to test it on my machine to make sure the patches work and did not break anything. but I know the previous errors I got so as long as no new errors then we should be fine

ghaskins
2016-11-08 14:28
in general "what worked before should still work" is a good mindset

ghaskins
2016-11-08 14:29
anything that is an enhancement beyond what worked before is a bonus...until we get to the end of the series and then we should def have new capability or I failed

garisingh
2016-11-08 14:29

ghaskins
2016-11-11 13:37

ghaskins
2016-11-11 13:37

ry
2016-11-11 13:49

ry
2016-11-11 13:50
I'm fairly conservative in the builds I write - I like to spew the environment and versions of everything directly into the console logs so you can see exactly how things were at the time you ran that specific build

jonathanlevi
2016-11-16 10:10
Note: Yes, certificates (aka “signed” certificates) are formatted according to a standard, but they are considered as “clear-text”.

yacovm
2016-11-16 10:11
you mean, encoded

jonathanlevi
2016-11-16 10:11
(yes, I used ‘formatted’ to avoid confusion with ‘encoded’ that may come across as coded/encrypted).

jonathanlevi
2016-11-16 10:13
We might not treat them as fully available pubic information (as they may contain attributes that say a lot), such as one’s Organizational Unit… say, if I have a list of ALL of IBM’s employees, then I would have been able to build the full directory structure.

jonathanlevi
2016-11-16 10:13
But on an individual basis, we do not treat a certificate as a “confidential”/encrypted piece of data.

jonathanlevi
2016-11-16 10:14
___ There is some cryptographic value in the EnrollmentID string though (esp. in v0.5 and the v0.6 branches), so that should not be considered as “completely public”… but certificates are “up for grabs” :wink:

simon
2016-11-16 11:13

simon
2016-11-16 11:15
right on, just make it less easy to write good commits

@ghaskins - https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2569/1

ghaskins
2016-11-17 22:44
gah, i hate the idea of this. ibm java is just broken

ghaskins
2016-11-17 22:44
it should ideally be fixed

muralisr
2016-11-17 22:45
@garisingh will look at 2503

ghaskins
2016-11-17 22:48
my preference would be in this order: a) ibmjava is fixed (this works on openjdk and oracle-java), b) we evaluate whether bootclasspath still accelerates startup (it used to)....if it no longer matters, we can disable it in the preamble and once again restore compatibility with the broken ibmjava...c) modify the lein-bin plugin to emit a script which special cases ibm-java and works around it, and lastly d) this hack

ghaskins
2016-11-17 22:48
my concern is, this patch fixes the peer runtime, but it doesnt address the fundamental problem and this wont help people that want to work with chaintool on ibmjava based setups

muralisr
2016-11-25 18:05
This is probably a well known issue, but was interesting as I ran into this first time when dealing with https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2761/. ```CR 1 - introduces change that will break CR 2 - passes CI and is merged CR 2 - was not based off CR1. - so passes CI and is merged After merge of CR2, subsequent CRs will fail CI``` This can only happen if CI runs before merge .. is this assumption correct @ramesh @ry @cbf ? If true, some of the fears that a CR was merged without waiting for CI to V+1 is likely baseless. It could just be dependencies slipping in.

yacovm
2016-11-25 19:03
Wait, `PR1`'s parent hash is `master`, and after `PR1` is applied to `master`, it becomes `master'` and PR2 needs a rebase, because its parent hash is still `master` and after a rebase it won't pass CI

muralisr
2016-11-25 20:48
if CR2 is rebased, yes… everything will be fine and CI will catch the failure. but if its not, and there are no conflicts, gerritt will signal it can be merged but CI will run BEFORE its merged

ry
2016-11-28 02:28
@muralisr: @yacovm : we could enable another merge method but it would mean every pending change would need rebased after every commit.

jzhang
2016-11-29 15:37
@garisingh @cbf @aso please review and merge the following two (must go together, one for fabric, one for sdk): https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2701 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2837

aso
2016-11-29 15:38
has joined #fabric-maintainers

aso
2016-11-29 15:44
@jzhang done - Btw: at some point we will have to reintroduce some header of sorts. I was thinking ASN.1 marshalling of an integer (that describes the type of identity, 1 for x.509, 2 for idemix etc...) followed by a byte array containing the serialized identity (currently, x.509 will use PEM encoding)

aso
2016-11-29 15:44
do we agree on this @jzhang @garisingh ?

jzhang
2016-11-29 15:48
@aso that’s reasonable, until idemix is introduced, assuming the certs are always sent in PEM format I think is sufficient since that seems to be the most prevalent way to exchange certs

jzhang
2016-11-29 15:48
will idemix introduce a new kind of cert format?

jzhang
2016-11-29 15:49
or encoding rule?

aso
2016-11-29 15:49
that is of course fine. At the same time, introducing this marshalled int (of with value 1) in front of the PEM byte array is something we can already to today, right?

aso
2016-11-29 15:49
and yes, idemix will have entirely different structures

aso
2016-11-29 15:49
so it'll have to be marshalled/unmarshalled in a different way

aso
2016-11-29 15:49
so for now I'd say we can marshal a "1" integer followed by the PEM encoding of the cert

aso
2016-11-29 15:50
and if/when idemix is introduced, they'll marhsal a "2" integer followed by their own structures

aso
2016-11-29 15:50
makes sense?

jzhang
2016-11-29 15:50
makes sense. i guess it’s better to introduce this before v1.0 goes out...

garisingh
2016-11-29 15:51
why not just use a protobuf struct?

jzhang
2016-11-29 15:51
...even if idemix does not come in during this time frame

jzhang
2016-11-29 15:52
right, there’s that question too, it’d be much easier to use protobuf than playing with ASN1 encoding

jzhang
2016-11-29 15:53
@hgabor @garisingh @jyellick @kostas I +1’d on https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2657, sorry for the delay

hgabor
2016-11-29 15:54
+2 given to 2657

2016-11-29 18:56

muralisr
2016-11-29 21:58

muralisr
2016-11-29 21:59
one thing struck me...

muralisr
2016-11-29 22:01
@muralisr uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/muralisr/F38HRLF45/pasted_image_at_2016_11_29_04_59_pm.png and commented: that’s from the CI console… if the above log is from the docker-compose (and it may not be ?) I’d expect this to have the right IP address instead of 0.0.0.0:7050

ghaskins
2016-11-29 22:33
@muralisr yeah, that is curious

ghaskins
2016-11-29 22:43
oh wait, I know what that is

ghaskins
2016-11-29 22:43
we don't currently run the orderer as part of the unit-tests

ghaskins
2016-11-29 22:43
the unit-tests use unit-test/docker-compose.yml

ghaskins
2016-11-29 22:44
whereas this CR is adding a test/docker-compose.yaml...it isnt consumed by any code

ghaskins
2016-11-29 22:44
its just there for human convenience

ghaskins
2016-11-29 22:44
there is a valid argument that somehow some of the orderer/peer compositions could be shared

ghaskins
2016-11-29 22:45
but I think we would need to do this carefully, there are subtle differences

ghaskins
2016-11-29 22:45
like, for instance, the ./test/docker-compose purposesly surfaces the peer as localhost ports

ghaskins
2016-11-29 22:46
this is useful for substituting "docker run --it hyperledger/fabric-peer" for places that used to run "peer node start" natively

ghaskins
2016-11-29 22:46
but it might not be so convenient for UTs which presumably should avoid potential port conflicts

keithsmith
2016-11-29 22:47
Could someone review https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2641/9 ? thanks

muralisr
2016-11-29 22:58
@ghaskins thanks for the detailed explanation! that helps (and just wanted to make sure … )

ghaskins
2016-11-29 22:59
np, and actually aside from my consolidation aspirations above, one could also argue that we should probably start the orderer for the UTs just to be complete

ghaskins
2016-11-29 22:59
even if there isn't anything that strictly uses them right now

ghaskins
2016-11-29 22:59
or are there valid deployments of a peer that have no orderer?

ghaskins
2016-11-29 23:00
I would think not, but I am not really sure

ghaskins
2016-11-30 01:21
@cbf: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2855/

ghaskins
2016-11-30 01:21
reduction of docker images from 1.4G to ~24M for peer/orderer

cbf
2016-11-30 01:24
:sunglasses:

ghaskins
2016-11-30 01:25
The CR is production grade, BUT, I do currently build busybox inline (takes about 5 minutes on my 2011 MBP)

ghaskins
2016-11-30 01:25
so, if we love the idea but hate the inline build, we can strategize on moving busybox to a static build

ghaskins
2016-11-30 01:26
few ideas: create fabric-busybox.git and the surrounding jenkins pipeline

ghaskins
2016-11-30 01:26
add it to the existing fabric-baseimage.git as a discrete artifact

ghaskins
2016-11-30 01:26
add it to baseimage.git as a binary included in the baseimage and extract the binary at build time, etc

ghaskins
2016-11-30 01:27
I am open

ghaskins
2016-11-30 01:27
I think between the 5 minutes + the fact that it gets cached after the first build, any of the options are viable

ghaskins
2016-11-30 01:27
depends on consensus here

jonathanlevi
2016-12-02 21:37
Do we have the int `sarama.MaxRequestSize` documented anywhere? [Yes, let’s state/document somewhere that this is the ‘quantity’ we use as a sending limit, or so]

jonathanlevi
2016-12-02 21:37
EDITED/REPHRASED: @sanchezl: will it be possible to have a test that fails without the fix, and passes with it? I feel that simply relying on that external constant may not suffice (say, if it changes/we vendor a new version, etc. - we may not be able to flag that. It will be good to add a physical/fixed boundary check(s)…)

2016-12-02 23:28

2016-12-03 17:29
@garisingh @cbf https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2933 is ready for review

jzhang
2016-12-03 19:47
@muralisr: yes that's what we've been doing, but given the 100+ steps involved it's not obvious where the gap is ;-)

muralisr
2016-12-03 19:47

muralisr

cbf
2016-12-04 15:11
@jzhang @garisingh I don't understand why we haven't got an associated change to fabric for https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2933

cbf
2016-12-04 15:11
I think it is a mistake to merge a change that breaks the over-all system.

muralisr
2016-12-04 15:38
+1 @cbf ^^^ … @jzhang @harrisob you probably have a reason why shouldn’t wait for the fix ?

jzhang
2016-12-04 19:18
@cbf @muralisr so the work to figure out why the hashes (one by endorser and another one by committer) don’t compare is incredibly difficult. @harrisob and Murali spent a long time on this together and couldn’t nail it down. in the meanwhile the SDK team need this changeset to get back in sync with the fabric (mainly for the proto changes), as soon as possible. that’s the background. as for specific ways to handle this gap, I agree submitting a changeset to disable the hash compare in the peer code is a better way to go, rather than asking every SDK developers and users to make that change in the Peer

muralisr
2016-12-04 19:22
@jzhang we did narrow it down (or I thught so) to one signing that was done in CLI but wasn’t in SDK. … I can take a look at that if you like

muralisr
2016-12-04 19:43
@jzhang it is true we couldn’t figure out why the hashes are different… and `the SDK team need this changeset to get back in sync with the fabric (mainly for the proto changes), as soon as possible` is compelling. PErhaps we open a JIRA to keep eye on the ball ?

muralisr
2016-12-04 19:47
If you open a defect and assign to me, I’ll fix it by doing the check but not error out… just print a log warning

jzhang
2016-12-04 20:02
thanks @muralisr, will do

muralisr
2016-12-04 20:02
(assuming @cbf @garisingh are ok with that… ?

cbf
2016-12-04 20:03
no, we fix it... come on guys

cbf
2016-12-04 20:04
you can't have a changeset that "gets you back in synch" with fabric if you have to hack fabric to get it to work

cbf
2016-12-04 20:04
submit the corresponding fix, please

jzhang
2016-12-04 20:06
@muralisr https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1262

jzhang
2016-12-04 20:08
@cbf I’m a little confused by what you are saying above, Murali is proposing exactly what you suggested first to check in the hack to allow the SDK 2933 to be merged

jzhang
2016-12-04 20:08
I’ll submit another two in JIRA to fix the SDK and revert that hack in peer

jzhang
2016-12-04 20:09
that sounds about right to you?

cbf
2016-12-04 20:09
ah, ok, I misunderstood - what was the point of a JIRA to track the defect?

cbf
2016-12-04 20:10
if we are fixing the problem, I am good with that - who submits is not important

jzhang
2016-12-04 20:10
ok, so Murali will put in a fix for 1262

jzhang
2016-12-04 20:11
that fix itself is harmless to the fabric, so it can go in as soon as it’s ready. then https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2933 can be merged after your reviews

muralisr
2016-12-04 20:13
@cbf.. two options (1) disable the error on fabric (which is wha 1262) suggests so we don’t have to fix the SDK side immediately (2) find the bug and fix it in SDK… I think - rereading the comments above - you’d like option (2) and not option (1)

jzhang
2016-12-04 20:32
unfortunately 2) is not a good option given the circumstances, we have to recognize the special situation we are in: the whole proposal->proposalresponse->transaction process is manipulating some very complex objects with many steps in processsing, marshalling and unmarshalling in between. it’s going to take some more time to figure this one out. we need a way right now to allow the rest of the SDK team to progress and for the general community to try out sprint 6. fortunately, the hack needed to get us unstuck is “harmless” (no side effects). i don’t see why we shouldn’t do it right now.

jzhang
2016-12-04 20:32
@muralisr @cbf ^^^

garisingh
2016-12-04 21:04
well it's only "harmless" in that it basically disables proper checking :wink:

garisingh
2016-12-04 21:05
but I see what you mean.

garisingh
2016-12-04 21:05
as an aside, I have been VERY VERY worried about the complexity of the freaking protobufs and signatures over them. so this is not surprising

muralisr
2016-12-15 16:25

jzhang
2016-12-15 16:31
@jonathanlevi @garisingh @binhn @elli @adc can we get @aso's https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3293 reviewed and merged? the SDK are dependent on this to catch up to the latest fabric. the SDK has been broken for a while because of the ASN.1 based serialization that the SDK teams have been advocating to be removed, which this changeset replaces.

garisingh
2016-12-15 16:34
3293 looks good

adc
2016-12-15 16:34
Hi, I would like to point out that we are moving from a deterministic serialization mechanism (ASN.1), standard in crypto, to a non-deterministic serialization mechanism (protobuf), at least google does not guarantees deterministic serialization. This might cause problems later. It is better to have this in mind :slightly_smiling_face:

garisingh
2016-12-15 16:35
yeah - I had also offered just doing prefixing things with a byte to determine the type as well

garisingh
2016-12-15 16:35
BTW - we are serializing and signing protobufs in other areas as well :wink:

adc
2016-12-15 16:36
I hope we are doing that having in mind this serialization issue

muralisr
2016-12-15 16:59
most of all serialization in `fabric/core` (I wish I can confidently say ALL) happens in `protos/utils`

muralisr
2016-12-15 17:01
good to keep it that way … in general, all marshal/unmarshal under `protos` package where *.proto reside

jzhang
2016-12-15 17:20
@adc yes Gari has brought this up as well before but at least as far as the proposal/transaction processing cycles are concerned this is not a problem, as the bytes are generated by the SDK and signed then they are verified as-is throughout the process without being unmarshalled and marshalled again which would have hit the non-deterministic serialization issue. as far as I’m aware, that’s all we need to care about

jonathanlevi
2016-12-15 18:47
@jzhang https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3293 is merged

jonathanlevi
2016-12-15 18:55
@jonathanlevi set the channel topic: This channel is mostly for comms between maintainers. If you want to draw our (and others!) to your/a CR/PR, please kindly use #fabric-pr-review.

jonathanlevi
2016-12-15 18:57
@kostas ^^^ (“what you said”)

2016-12-15 19:57

kostas
2016-12-20 03:16
Not sure if this is related to a previous discussion on managing dependencies, but if we're looking for a new way to do this, I would suggest we wait for a few months.

kostas
2016-12-20 03:16
An official tool (part of the standard `go` toolchain) to handle dependencies is being worked on.

kostas
2016-12-20 03:17
There's a committee and a first (I guess, alpha) implementation planned towards the end of January: https://blog.gopheracademy.com/advent-2016/saga-go-dependency-management/

jonathanlevi
2016-12-22 13:12

yacovm
2016-12-28 16:18
2017 is approaching. Is it needed to change the year in the license? (in the file headers)

jonathanlevi
2016-12-28 16:34
Probably to update to 2016-17. Let me check with legal.

garisingh
2016-12-28 19:29
likely only for new files

ry
2016-12-29 03:54
I would remove years entirely. They only generate confusion. This is not legal advice, but my experience with that exact issue on several projects

ry
2016-12-29 03:55
If you keep years, you can't just update the year. You need a list, 2016-2017 for instance. Then you end up with 2016-2017,2019-2021 if a file is untouched for a while.

ry
2016-12-29 03:56
It's messy, brittle, and doesn't give you any information.

ry
2016-12-29 03:57
@yacovm: @jonathanlevi @garisingh

ghaskins
2016-12-29 04:37
:+1:

cbf
2017-01-03 13:37
for new files, use 2017... no need to go back and edit all of the headers.

cbf
2017-01-03 13:39
or we could omit altogether, but again, I would NOT edit existing content

muralisr
2017-01-03 18:33
@cbf @garisingh what do you think of a CR submission to Skip a select list of tests on chaincode ?

muralisr
2017-01-03 18:34
to reduce time… there’s enough duplication going on there I think

cbf
2017-01-03 18:34

ghaskins

cbf
2017-01-13 14:10
cbf$ docker run -it hyperledger/fabric-busybox /bin/sh / # which vi /bin/vi / #

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:10
@cbf, all, regarding our current busybox approach in general, I discovered a serious flaw last night

muralisr
2017-01-13 14:10
ok

cbf
2017-01-13 14:10
is that the dns one?

muralisr
2017-01-13 14:10
thanks much

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:10
yeah

cbf
2017-01-13 14:10
oops

cbf
2017-01-13 14:10
lol

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:10
heh

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:11
heh, I didnt notice until I was trying to get peer to talk to orderer in a composition via a link

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:11
the peer was failing to see the orderer, and then I couldnt see it via the (busybox) shell either

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:11
so I was thinking it was a problem with docker/compose/links

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:12
but it turns out, docker is fine: the way I have linked the peer/busybox binaries against glibc is I think the culprit

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:12
(its apparently a known limitation in glibc + static linking

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:13
anyway, i am formulating a fix, but it isnt trivial

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:14
@ghaskins uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ghaskins/F3R71RVDY/-.txt and commented: Good summary of the symptom

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:15
I will incorporate some aspect of this into UAT so we would catch it going forward

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:16
im partially inclined to start deriving our "runtime" image from alpine and let the P/Z folks worry about how they would optimize size independently

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:16
e.g. we could have x86 base come from alpine and P/Z could fall back to baseimage

cbf
2017-01-13 14:17
https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=757941

cbf
2017-01-13 14:17
?

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:17
aside from the fact that alpine has already solved this issue, it would also be forward looking for when we need a light weight JVM container too

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:18
@cbf I havent seen that particular report, but at first blush, i think thats the same issue

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:19
basically, we are compiling peer/orderer/busybox on ubuntu, so the static link is picking up whatever libc is naturally there

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:19
in this case, glibc

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:19
im looking at a bunch of options

hgabor
2017-01-13 14:20
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3633/

cbf
2017-01-13 14:24
glibc claims fixed

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:25
perhaps I just need to update the v0.2.2 baseimage

cbf
2017-01-13 14:26
which busybox are you using?

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:27
well, 1.25.1 is whats in the CR but I have a latest (1.26.2) in an unpushed patch locally

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:27
didnt make a difference

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:27
(plus, it wouldnt solve the statically linked peer/orderer

cbf
2017-01-13 14:27
which glibc are we using?

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:27
let me look

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:28
@ghaskins uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ghaskins/F3R58BHHR/-.txt

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:29
here are some options I am exploring

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:29
1) perhaps there is a newer glibc for ubuntu and I just need to apt-get upgrade and be done

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:29
2) ubuntu has some support for musl, not sure how easy it will be to get go/busybox to link with it

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:30
3) switch bases for runtime (e.g. alpine)

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:30
(3) does have the advantage that it will be easy to build a micro-jre container (thinking chaintool and the java chaincode)

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:30
but the disadvantage is I would be leaving P/Z out in the cold

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:31
(the workaround for them is they could use standard ubuntu until someone optimizes for size)

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:31
so not like they wouldnt work, they just wouldnt be optimized containers

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:35
so, there is an update for that package

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:35
ill try getting baseimage updated and see if that fixes it (for option (1))

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:42
@cbf as a rule of thumb, perhaps we want to take a hit and "apt-get upgrade" baseimage during the build?

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:42
not sure this will address this particular problem, but just thinking about general CVE type things

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:43
on one hand, the notion of a non-deterministic operation bothers me a little...on the other, the fact that we are based on an LTS image somewhat mitigates the negative aspects of non-determinism

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:51
@ghaskins uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ghaskins/F3QH1JW3B/-.c and commented: @cbf running a build with this patch now

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:51
will see if that changes anything at least w.r.t. busybox DNS

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:55
@cbf no dice

ghaskins
2017-01-13 14:56
same behavior with latest glibc (on xenial, at least) and v1.26.2

cbf
2017-01-13 14:57
hmmm

hgabor
2017-01-13 14:58
could somebody review this? https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3633/ I had two +2s but had to rebase

ghaskins
2017-01-13 15:12
@cbf heres another possibility I am exploring

ghaskins
2017-01-13 15:12
https://sourceware.org/glibc/wiki/FAQ#Even_statically_linked_programs_need_some_shared_libraries_which_is_not_acceptable_for_me.__What_can_I_do.3F

ghaskins
2017-01-13 15:13
e.g. we can control the linker, so I might be able to specifically link nss_files/dns and we are good to go

ghaskins
2017-01-13 15:17
ill take this over to fabric-dev

2017-01-14 06:26

adc
2017-01-16 07:15
Hi @jzhang, the implementation there is finished. The point is that I cannot ask to merge that change-set if the clients do not change first because otherwise there will be a certain number of valid transactions rejected because they have an invalid signature with the respect to the new rules. Just that

2017-01-16 17:49

jonathanlevi
2017-01-19 18:05
MERGE FREEZE *BEGIN* [`fabric-ca` only] As we are now at the final step of the renaming of `fabric-cop` to `fabric-ca` - *maintainers*, please let’s not *merge* any new CRs to fabric-ca until further announcement. People may continue to develop and submit CRs with no interruption. We would like to just hold-off any code merges from any maintainer. Thanks.

cbf
2017-01-26 17:39
so, we are approaching a desired release, but it is unclear to me (please correct me if I missed it) whether we have mapped out a plan of attack

ghaskins
2017-01-26 17:40
Theres a couple of things that I would deem blocking before that can happen

dave.enyeart
2017-01-26 17:43
and there are many reviews outstanding for things desired to get in

ghaskins
2017-01-26 17:44
One is the baseos/DNS fix (https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1652), and the other is fixing the SDK/Peer to not send Dockerfiles any more (https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-678)

ghaskins
2017-01-26 17:44
both are in progress, as I am sure many others are too as @dave.enyeart points out

ghaskins
2017-01-26 17:45
the latter is ABI impacting...so, one plan of attack that I would highly encourage is focusing on ABI convergence

ghaskins
2017-01-26 17:45
we really really really dont want to break that after 1.0, at least, not until 2.0 minimally

ghaskins
2017-01-26 17:45
other things may be patched

ghaskins
2017-01-26 17:46
specifically, wire ABI

arnaud
2017-01-26 17:48

ghaskins
2017-01-27 19:34
I would suggest subversioning that, like 1.0.0-alpha1

ghaskins
2017-01-27 19:34
just a hunch, but I doubt this will be the only cut :wink:

garisingh
2017-01-27 19:41
yah

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:04
@garisingh this is still WIP (on account of I need to address a CI bug in CR4771), but I wanted you to be aware: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/4943/

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:05
if accepted, this would mean clients/CLI no longer need to supply a Dockerfile, thus fixing the "baseimage:latest not found" issues we have been plagued with forever

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:06
rather, the peer with synthesize the correct tag based on its config/arch, and if necessary pull it from dockerhub

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:07
the expected CI failure will likely be the CR4771 issue I mentioned, on account of 4943 being queued behind it

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:08
opps, looks like I hit some _other_ unrelated issue on master atm

jzhang
2017-01-27 20:14
@ghaskins not requiring baseimage:lastest to be set up first would be a huge improvement

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:14
yeah, it will auto manage it

jzhang
2017-01-27 20:15
yep

jzhang
2017-01-27 20:15
so basically docker pull of the baseimage can happen during deploy right?

jzhang
2017-01-27 20:15
the first deploy

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:15
I have an SDK patch which removes the dockerfile generation still pending, but even if an "older" (meaning, older than whenever the patch gets merged), the peer will just ignore the provided file

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:16
I have a mental "todo" to make the peer issue a WARN log when it finds a payload with a Dockerfile in it though

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:16
just to reduce confusion

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:16
"I _swear_ I put this RUN statement in there!?!?!?"

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:17
but other than the removal of the tarball, the ABI of the payload that the SDK/CLI provides is the same

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:17
so, it should be a relatively smooth transition

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:17
note that also, master utilizes ccenv rather than the raw baseimage, which already has the shim

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:17
so, no need to vendor shim (per se)

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:17
unless you want a different version

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:18
it also means that CAR support should be trivial when I get to that point

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:20
@jzhang sorry, forgot to address your question

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:20
yes, it will be pulled down if not already there

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:20
by the peer, i mean, not human/external intervention

jzhang
2017-01-27 20:20
right

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:21
you may already know this, but a while back I templatized the peer's processing of the Dockerfile

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:21
for instance, in core/yaml, you see these: FROM hyperledger/fabric-ccenv:$(ARCH)-$(PROJECT_VERSION)

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:22
so the peer will substitute the correct parameters at runtime to match the ARCH/VER that its running on

ghaskins
2017-01-27 20:22
this was done in prep for CR4943, but has just been more or less irrelevant until now
