jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 00:36
Maintainers, a quick one: so as some of us noticed last night (and thanks @c0rwin for spending time on this) that we have an issue with a dependency on a C library (https://github.com/opendnssec/SoftHSMv2) after merging some code yesterday.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 00:37
Repro: we can reproduce “only” if we `go test ./…` which executes the tests recursively in fabric.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 00:39
I would rather not revert the code and resolve this dependency. Noting that’s a C library (so `go get` does not do the trick) - but we can still either use the make file or pre-build it and have it available to the dev...

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 00:39
Or, alternatively, condition the tests...

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 00:41
Please can you chime in? https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/4929/2 [ I appreciate that it’s Friday afternoon -> mainly want opinions… ]

ghaskins
2017-01-28 02:07
hmm, i was apprehensive about approving that softhsm addition outright for these kinds of reasons

ghaskins
2017-01-28 02:07
i was told it was test-time only so I was ok with that

ghaskins
2017-01-28 02:08
but it sounds like we are carrying the baggage in the binary too?

ghaskins
2017-01-28 02:08
or is it only w.r.t. go-test?

binhn
2017-01-28 02:36
i will have another cr for chaincode calling chaincode to be submitted tonight or early tomorrow

binhn
2017-01-28 02:57
@ghaskins soft hsm should be for test only, though i am not clear on how it is being packaged

harrijk
2017-01-28 04:24
softhsm2 was only installed in the testenv docker image. The bccsp/pkcs11 unit tests rely on using the softhsm2 utility. I guess those unit tests aren't taking into account of running unit tests outside of the testenv image (??)

weeds
2017-01-28 09:59
Wanted to say thanks to the maintainers. Realize there has been a lot to review this week as we try to spint up an image for people to be able to use at the Hackfest- thank you for all the help!

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 15:28
Likewise...

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 15:30
Same here - and it took me some time to also confirm that the LICENSE is not an issue, but approved it after having told the same (that it’s temporarily + people needed it for now + some are away next week -> so wanted it a day later so that we have a few CI iterations over/with it.)

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 15:32
@binhn, @harrijk: Yes, let’s have it only in the image then (as long as we/) and make sure that everyone can pick up a cut of the code locally and test it in full without an issue...

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 15:32
For the hackfest or otherwise.

harrijk
2017-01-28 15:36
For those that are truly interested in running the bccsp/pkcs11 unit tests using the softhsm2 utility, they can either run `make unit-test` with the TEST_PKGS env variable set to the desired pkcs11 tests, or run a testenv container and perform specific pkcs11 tests there.

harrijk
2017-01-28 15:38
I tested https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/4929/2 on z and it looks like it addresses the case where folks aren't interested in using the softhsm2 utility while running unit tests outside of the testenv docker container.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 15:57
@harrijk Yes, ok. So we can have the pkcs11 tests not specified in the TEST_PKGS by default, so that `make unit-test` ignore them. I agree.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 15:59
Now, the main question (left) is whether we would like to support also the `go test ./…` command out of the box… or are we happy to limit users to use our make. Again, looking for opinions, mostly. [*Sorry for the editing, just having a strong coffee*]

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 15:59
[Happy to do the “leg work” and fix it, either way]

harrijk
2017-01-28 16:00
I think we should be happy scoping this within the testenv docker container (make). The audience interested in pkcs11 specifically, in my opinion, is a very low number at this point.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 16:01
Oh, clearly! Yes, I’m not that worried about these tests at this point, to be honest. I’m totally with you there!

harrijk
2017-01-28 16:01
re: TEST_PKGS, I was suggesting this could be used for folks specifically interested in running just pkcs11 tests (by-passing all other tests).

harrijk
2017-01-28 16:02
A quick method for pkcs11 unit tests using the softhsm2 library

harrijk
2017-01-28 16:02
Hopefully, I'm making sense. :slightly_smiling_face: I tend to ramble.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 16:03
No, you are fine. I understand you.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 16:03
OK, while I usually don’t like doing that, I can also put my cowboy hat and suggest a “hack” at times…

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 16:05
So I while `go` lets us have the `-short` flag that executes only the tests that check the `Short()` predicate… unfortunately, it’s not on by default… so that would not help here. However, instead:

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 16:06
We can also set/check for a temporary ENV VAR, `FABRIC_TEST_PKCS11` or `FABRIC_TEST_EXTRA_PACKAGES` or something along these lines (*highlighting as naming variables is always an interesting topic!* :slightly_smiling_face: )...

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 16:07
So that we test ONLY if these env variables are set. So that the regular/naive/trivial/expected `go test ./…` would still skip these.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 16:07
Thoughts?

harrijk
2017-01-28 16:08
....thinking...

harrijk
2017-01-28 16:11
CR-4929 by default, would by-pass pkcs11 unit tests within a "native" test (go test ./...) environment.

harrijk
2017-01-28 16:12
If folks would like to test pkcs11 outside of the testenv docker image, they would have to install softhsm2 on their local machine.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 16:13
Yes, that’s how we got “here” :wink:

harrijk
2017-01-28 16:13
ha

harrijk
2017-01-28 16:14
Yes, we got here because the pkcs11 unit tests didn't check for the existence of the softhsm2 libraries. Hopefully, CR-4929 is a good first step.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 16:16
Yup, I’m happy with this:

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 16:16
I’m happy with this (too), I should write.

harrijk
2017-01-28 16:18
If folks are interested in testing pkcs11 (and not by-passing those tests with CR-4929 in place) natively, to eliminate the pain of installing another package (softhsm2), perhaps we can take advantage of testenv docker containers and expose the softhsm2 library and token directories to the developer's local machine.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 16:19
Works for me.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 16:19
(Docker makes it simpler, indeed)

harrijk
2017-01-28 16:19
Just thinking "on the fly"

harrijk
2017-01-28 16:19
I'll see what I can come up with.

ghaskins
2017-01-28 17:09
I am fine with saying "make unit-test" is the only blessed way to run tests

ghaskins
2017-01-28 17:10
while it may be possible to run other ways, caveat emptor

ghaskins
2017-01-28 17:10
id say this is preferable to disabling a UT

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 17:16
Greg; Yes, and we can also document this accordingly. Happy with both John and Gregs - other opinions suggestions/welcome… will give it some time and push a CR shortly.

garisingh
2017-01-28 18:27
@harrijk - I thought that we actually already did this? At least I had suggested this to @vpaprots and I thought I saw this in one of the initial checkins for SoftHSM. Perhaps I am missing something and/or misunderstanding what you are saying. In any case, I'm fine with it

garisingh
2017-01-28 18:28
Maybe we also need to tell people about the TEST_PKGS environment variable which allows you to run `make unit-tests` and it will actually just test the package(s) specified

keithsmith
2017-01-28 19:35
WRT fabric-ca for alpha, here are the change sets which need attention. https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/4909 - This is a readthedocs update to contain fabric-ca user's guide info. It assumes the following 2 change sets get merged. https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/4369/ - bug fix for NPE, already has 2 +2's https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/4973/ - bug fix for enroll command I also need to make one more change set to update the README.md for fabric-ca so that it only contains developer info.

harrijk
2017-01-28 20:14
@garisingh Yes, you are correct. There were checks implemented in CR-4701 within *impl_test.go*. I should have been more clear. The issue that was encountered was that the *impl_test.go* code did not exit the test if no PKCS11 library was found. CR-4929 adds an `os.Exit(0)` if the check for a valid PKCS11 library is not found. Sorry for the confusion.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-28 20:59
@keithsmith: Please use #fabric-pr-review

garisingh
2017-01-28 21:38
@harrijk - no worries - makes sense now

sagmeister
2017-01-30 14:52
has joined #fabric-maintainers

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:01
@binhn: @cbf @garisingh and I were chatting earlier, wanted to loop you (and anyone else that cares) in

cbf
2017-01-30 18:01
https://wiki.hyperledger.org/projects/fabric/release-process

cbf
2017-01-30 18:01
the wiki is misbehaving but that is the page I was transferring from the old fabric wiki

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:02
I had expressed some reservations about creating a formal release at this stage...my experience with the state of the code coupled with my experience last time we released artifacts to dockerhub make me recommend that we hold off a bit

cbf
2017-01-30 18:02
I tend to share those reservations

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:02
though I also understand and appreciate the desire to have a smooth and productive hackfest

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:02
so we were trying to strategize on how to best do that

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:03
here is a summary of my sentiment: last go round we pushed images out to dockerhub before we were really ready to offer a dockerhub model

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:03
as a result, lots of users were confused, and who knows how many simply gave up without asking for help

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:04
i wanted to avoid that happening again

binhn
2017-01-30 18:04
@cbf that one misses a couple of steps that greg just pinged me — i’ll update the page

cbf
2017-01-30 18:04
thanks

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:04
we are getting closer to actually offering a dockerhub model (e.g. FAB-678) and I expect to rapidly converge on that in the next few weeks

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:05
but its not quite there yet

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:05
couple that to the fact that, in my experience the last few weeks, the code base itself is in pretty fragile state

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:05
therefore, my vote would be to hold off on any kind of formal release

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:06
that said, I will respect the consensus of all the maintainers

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:06
to the point of hackfest experience, the thought was perhaps an alternate dockerhub ns could be used

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:07
one that should ideally make it both easy for hackfest attendees to have a smooth experience and to also convey to the broader community that this is something specific to the hackfest, not a general release (pre-alpha or not)

binhn
2017-01-30 18:08
we currently have docker images and document to walk users through step by step; it is probably not inline with fab-678, but solid for developers to deploy chaincodes and write apps using SDK (limited APIs now)

binhn
2017-01-30 18:09
of course things will continue to improve as we move into beta next month

binhn
2017-01-30 18:09
but I think it is important that we give app developers something to work with now

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:10
I understand, just from my experience fielding all the questions about things like "baseimage:latest", most users tend to "shoot" (ala "docker run") first and ask questions later

cbf
2017-01-30 18:10
@binhn right so I think that the idea of publishing this (manually) to sfhackfest22017 is the right decision - @ramesh is working on setting that up, I believe

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:10
we currently dont really act like a typical docker container experience

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:10
after FAB-678, we will

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:12
and again, its just my vote: i dont think we are ready, but I wont obstruct consensus

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:12
if this is what we all agree we want, i will help make it happen

binhn
2017-01-30 18:13
we can package it as sfhackfest22017 and make that available, but we do need to decide on criteria for alpha — if we agree fab-678 then we’ll focus on that

binhn
2017-01-30 18:15
i am ok with pushing for fab-678 to alpha

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:16
i think minimally FAB-678, yes...my experience using the general suite the last few weeks did not give me the impression we were the epitome of stability either...that would also be pre-req...but I recognize that its a rapidly moving target and that is likely contributing to the stability, perceived or otherwise

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:17
currently I run a series of duct-tape and chewing gum patches on top of the upstream tree just to hobble things together, and any time I move HEAD things generally break

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:17
and then getting those fixes, breaks other things, etc

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:17
heh

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:17
its a frustrating game of whack-a-mole

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:18
if we can nail ABI, stablity, and FAB-678, then I would feel confident in making the cut

binhn
2017-01-30 18:19
yes, the last few weeks were very rough — things just stable in the last few days (ABI, especially protos are fixed now)

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:19
thats good, that will help

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:20
sort of in the ABI space, FAB-678 will change the deployment CodePackage spec, FYI, though I anticipate it will be predominantly backwards compatible

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:20
basically, I anticipate the CodePackage will look exactly as it does today...the difference is clients/SDKs may omit the Dockerfile

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:21
ideally, we can get them all fixed so they _dont_ include it, just because I think it would lead to confusion

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:21
but in the end, we can just safely ignore any Dockerfiles included if there are stragglers

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:22
I suppose we have some ABI flexibility coming out of alpha though

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:22
this is more of a v1.0 criteria

binhn
2017-01-30 18:23
we certain do as requirements/feedback from users

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:24
right, ok

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:24
so, scratch that part, though I suspect it will get updated just a part of FAB-678 anyway

binhn
2017-01-30 18:25
another thing i am considering is to use CAR to package chaincode

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:25
ah, good, i am close to having that supported in v1.0

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:25
actually I am close to having most of FAB-678 working

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:25
mostly working on peripheral kinks

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:26
for instance, these three patches implement most of the peer side

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:26
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/4943/

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:26
but a bug (I suspect on the Jenkins side) is causing the CI failure

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:26
still investigating

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:27
I also have the node-sdk and chaintool patches in queue

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:27
so, I am confident it can be wrapped up in short order, though not in time for hackfest

binhn
2017-01-30 18:29
sounds good, so we will proceed to package a docker images for hackfest. I have asked Ramesh to work with you this week to help with fab-678

ghaskins
2017-01-30 18:29
ok, ty

cbf
2017-02-01 21:33
@ghaskins @hgabor @tamas @garisingh @jonathanlevi @binhn @jyellick @sheehan @muralisr @yacovm Gari and I were discussing how we handle our documentation

cbf
2017-02-01 21:35
one approach we considered was create a fabric-docs project that was effectively a shell repo that links in submodules of the other project repos to create an aggregate repo that we could use to build the aggregate RTD

cbf
2017-02-01 21:36
@ry did some investigation and opendaylight uses this approach

cbf
2017-02-01 21:36
https://github.com/opendaylight/docs

cbf
2017-02-01 21:36
I think that it would make sense for us to pursue the same approach

cbf
2017-02-01 21:37
@ry is going to incorporate the git submodule plugin for Gerrit, and once that is available, we should be able to start the process of establishing the fabric-docs project

cbf
2017-02-01 21:37
all we need is a bunch of +1s from the maintainers to do this

ghaskins
2017-02-01 22:14
@cbf it makes sense, but submodules can be tricky

ghaskins
2017-02-01 22:15
@ecblseg and I managed a project that was based on them, and it can get messy

ecblseg
2017-02-01 22:15
has joined #fabric-maintainers

ghaskins
2017-02-01 22:15
not saying we shouldnt do it this way, but be warned

ghaskins
2017-02-01 22:15
there will def be confused users

ry
2017-02-01 22:23
@ghaskins agreed, it can be confusing

cbf
2017-02-01 23:57
@ghaskins yes, they can be, but this is pretty straight forward

sheehan
2017-02-02 00:32
I've never used submodules myself, but @bobsummerwill has suggested careful evaluation before using them based on his experience with cpp-ethereum https://lists.hyperledger.org/pipermail/hyperledger-fabric/2016-July/000167.html. He lists some good points/questions at https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/hyperledger-fabric/2016-September/000320.html. I’m not sure if these pre-cautions would apply to a docs only repo.

bobsummerwill
2017-02-02 00:33
has joined #fabric-maintainers

hgabor
2017-02-02 14:01
@cbf I like the idea of having a fabric-docs! +1 or do we have a dedicated poll/changeset/something for this? (to vote)

weeds
2017-02-02 23:32
FYI- People at the hackfest in San Fran. had questions on proposed content for the alpha release for Fabric- This is the current proposed list: https://wiki.hyperledger.org/projects/proposedv1alphacontent . This is not a finalized list but what is being proposed. If you have additions or items to be removed that you want to suggest, I would recommend communicating this on the fabric-maintainers channel. If there are changes to be made to the list @claytonsims can make them once a decision is made.
